rationale: The species is assessed as Least Concern as it has a large distribution area and there are no known widespread threats to this species.
habitat:
This species inhabits rivers, lakes, reservoirs, ponds and ditches (Man and Hodgkiss 1981, Etnier and Starnes 1993) with stagnant or slow-flowing water (Billard 1997). It occurs in eutrophic fresh and brackish waters, well vegetated ponds and canals (Kottelat and Freyhof 2007). The maximum recorded salinity is 17 ppt, but it is unable to withstand prolonged exposure above 15 ppt (Schwartz 1964). It feeds on a wide range of food including plants, small crustaceans, insects, and detritus (Kottelat and Freyhof 2007). The species usually lives up to about 20 years under artificial conditions.

It is oviparous, with pelagic larvae. It spawns when water temperatures reach 15-20 °C. Juveniles require high temperature to grow. Individual females spawn with a few males in dense vegetation. The eggs are sticky, attached to water plants or other submerged objectives.
threats: No threats to this species are known.
population: <span class="short_text" id="result_box">There is no information available on the species' population within its natural distribution range.
range:
The species is reported to be native to East Asia: from the Amur River to the Pearl River basin including the Korean Peninsula and Taiwan (Freyhof and Kottelat 2007). It was domesticated in China more than 1,000 years ago, introduced to Japan in the 16th century and from Japan imported to Europe: Portugal 1611, England 1691 and France 1755. From then it was introduced throughout Europe and most of the world.

It was introduced throughout the world as the Asian form of the goldfish. Several countries report adverse ecological impact after introduction.

This is possibly the species (or Carassioides acuminatus) "Pa Fek" that has been introduced into the Nam Theun reservoir in Lao PDR where it has established very well.
useTrade: The species is valued as ornamental fish for ponds and aquaria; it is edible but rarely eaten (Frimodt 1995). It is also used as an experimental species (Robinson et al. 1991).
conservationActions: None required.

rationale: The species is only native to central and southern China where it has been declining due to dams, overfishing and loss of habitat. The species may be threatened and is therefore assessed as Data Deficient due to the lack of knowledge regarding species population size and current population trends  and threats in its natural distribrution range.
habitat: In its natural distribution range, inhabits rivers with marked water-level fluctuations, overwinters in middle and lower stretches. Lives up to 20 years. Spawns for the first time at 5-6 years, 550-700 mm SL and 5-10 kg, earlier and smaller in subtropical areas. Migrates long distances upriver at the beginning of a rapid flood and water-level increases (in April-July depending on locality). Spawns during floods. Stops spawning if condition change and starts again with increase of water level. Spawns in upper water layer or even at water surfaces. Females spawn up to 1.1 million eggs in 1-3 portions depending on duration of high-water period. Eggs are yellowish, transparent, and hatch after about 2 days at temperatures around 25°C while drifting downstream in the deep open-water layer. If the river flow is blocked or if available river stretches are too short, eggs cannot drift long enough and fail to develop. After spawning, adults leave the river and migrate back to forage habitats. Larvae drift downstream and settle in floodplain lakes, shallow shores and backwaters with little or no current. In autumn-winter, when temperatures falls to 10°C, juveniles and adults form separate large schools and move downstream to deeper places in the main course of river to overwinter. Feed mostly on zooplankton, also algae. Often crossed with H. molitrix (source: Kottelat and Freyhof 2007).
threats: Major threats to Hypophthalmichthys nobilis in its native distribution range are overfishing and river modifications (e.g. dams, dykes and floodgate construction and reclamation of floodplains into agriculture land) (Duan et. al 2009).
population: In the second half of the 20th century, a marked decline in the abundance of this species was observed in its natural distribution range.
range: Hypophthalmichthys nobilis is reported to be native to central and south China (Kottelat and Freyhof 2007). Introduced to numerous countries and has achieved a near global distribution. Established reproductive populations in Europe, North America and Central Asia.
useTrade: Hypophthalmichthys nobilis is a commercially important fish species in China with high abundance in the catch (Wu et al. 2000). It is also used in aquaculture. Marketed fresh and frozen.
conservationActions: It is not known if there are any conservation measures in place. More research and monitoring is recommended.

rationale: A widespread species with no known major widespread threats, it is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat:
This species inhabits coastal waters, estuaries and lagoons, including brackish waters.

It is a coastal and estuarine species that is semi-catadromous, with some individuals either remaining in marine or estuarine waters throughout life, while others penetrate long distances into freshwater nurseries. 

Barramundi are opportunistic predators; crustaceans and fish predominate in the diet of adults (Larson 1999). Juveniles also consume insects (Allen et al. 1999). It is mostly found over soft bottom, hard bottom and rocky substrate (Allen et al. 2002); they are also reported to frequent coral reefs (Nguyen and Nguyen 2006). In fresh water habitats, Barramundi prefer cover on undercut banks, submerged logs and overhanging vegetation (Allen et al. 2002).

Lates calcarifer is known to be a protandrous hermaphrodite in Australia (Moore 1979), but sex change in Asian populations of this species is less well defined and primary females are common. Females are generally absent in the smaller length classes, but dominate larger length classes. Most Barramundi mature first as males and function as males for one or more spawning seasons before undergoing sex inversion. A few females will develop directly from immature fish (Davis 1987). Similarly, some males may never undergo sex inversion (Davis 1987). Length at first maturity for males in Australia is between 29 and 60 cm and an unsexed individual in the Indo-Pacific measured 90 cm.

Spawning seasonality varies within the range of this species. Barramundi are broadcast spawners that aggregate to spawn (Kailola et al. 1993). Barramundi in northern Australia spawn between September and March, with latitudinal variation in spawning season, presumably in response to varying water temperatures (Allen et al. 2002). In the Philippines, Barramundi spawn from late June to late October, while in Thailand spawning is associated with the monsoon season, with two peaks during the northeast monsoon (August – October) and the southwest monsoon (February – June) (Buschmann et al. 1996). Spawning occurs near river mouths, in the lower reaches of estuaries, or around coastal headlands (MacKinnon et al. 1986), and sometimes in the tidal flats near river mouths (Kailola et al. 1993). Barramundi spawn after the full and new moons during the spawning season, and spawning activity is usually associated with incoming tides that apparently assist transport of eggs and larvaer into the estuary (Bushcmann et al. 1996). 

While adults and juveniles are capable of living in fresh water, brackish waters are required for embryonic development (Shaklee and Salini 1985). Barramundi are highly fecund; a single female (120 cm TL) may produce 30–40 million eggs, or 2.3 million eggs per kg of body weight (Davis 1984). Under hatchery conditions, larvae grow to juveniles in 26 days (MacKinnon 1987). The postlarvae (and possibly larvae) move from spawning areas to brackish water seasonal habitat (Russell and Garrett 1985). Larval Barramundi occupy these habitats as well as main channels of streams (Kailola et al. 1993). Juveniles live in freshwater lagoons, swamps and creeks (Russell and Garett 1985). As these temporary habitats dry up, the juveniles move into the main stream and many migrate upstream to permanent freshwater habitats (Kailola et al. 1993). Juvenile Barramundi remain in freshwater habitats until they are three–four years of age (60–70 cm TL) when they reach sexual maturity as males, and then move downstream during the breeding season to participate in spawning. Because Barramundi are euryhaline, they can be cultured in a range of salinities, from fresh to seawater. When they are six–eight years old (85–100 cm TL), Australian Barramundi change sex to female and remain female for the rest of their lives (Kailola et al. 1993).

Lates calcarifer grows very quickly, achieving 1,500 to 3,000 g in one year (Hora and Pillay 1962). Although some Barramundi have been recorded as undertaking extensive movements between river systems, most of them remain in their original river system and move only short distances. This limited exchange of individuals between river systems is one factor that has contributed to the development of genetically distinct groups of Barramundi in northern Australia, where there are six recognised genetic strains in Queensland, and a further ten in the Northern Territory and Western Australia (FAO Cultured Aquatic Species Information Programme).
threats:
Loss of habitat through damming, mangrove destruction and overfishing are the key threats to the species.

There are no know threats towards this fish in The Gulf region. However, it should be noted that studies suggest that heavy aquaculture of this species is potentially leading to lower allele variation and less genetic diversity of aquacultured stocks when compared to wild-bred stocks (Yue et al. 2009), which breed-and-release programmes should be aware of and conduct further studies as to how this can lower genetic diversity in the wild.

A study published in 2010 showed that L. calcarifer fish caught off the southwestern coast of India revealed that this species has higher bioaccumulation of trace metals that other individuals of the same species inhabiting other waters in its range, and Cadmium had accumulated to toxic to human levels (Rejomon et al. 2010).
population:
No information is available on the population of this species across its range. The magnitude and timing of the wet season is likely to impact the juvenile success rate in this species. This is also a commercially fished species with harvest  records suggesting that commercial catch peaked in 2011 (Saunders, Whybird and Newman 2016).

Lates calcarifer is very well represented in museum collections, with 331 lots worldwide (FishNet2 retrieved 28 January 2014).

In Papua New Guinea in the late 1980s, Barramundi was ranked fourth in terms of both total fish production and foreign-exchange earnings (Opnai and Tenakanai 1987). The Barramundi catch represented ~80% of the total weight of commercial seafood sold in Daru in 1995 (Milton et al. 1998). In the early 1970s, commercial fishing vessels and artisanal fishers landed around 330 tonnes of L. calcarifer per year in just the Western province of Daru, around the Fly River region. However, intense local fishing depleted the local stock to the extent that the commercial fishing enterprises shut down in 1990 due to a lack of landings, most probably occurring because of stock depletion from over fishing (Milton et al. 1998).
range: This species is recorded from Indo-West Pacific; eastern edge of the Persian Gulf to China, Taiwan and southern Japan, southward to southern Papua New Guinea and northern Australia. In India, it is present in coastal brackish water areas of West Bengal, Orissa. It is probably not present in southern India. It has been recorded from Myanmar and Bangladesh.
useTrade:
This is a coastal, estuarine and freshwater species, and in India much of the catch is landed in winter. It enters estuaries and backwaters in pursuit of food and shelter but always returns to marine environments for spawning. Australian commercial fisheries generally cease fishing during the wet season (summer months) but this is managed by the different states or territories (e.g. Western Australia, Northern Territory and Queensland).

Juveniles of the species frequent the lower estuarine areas in the Hooghly-Matlah river system and enter impoundments along with the tidal water which acts as the main source of seed for brackish-water fish culture in impoundments popularly known as 'Bhasabadha' fishes in west Bengal. This prime estuarine perch comes into the Chilka Lake (Orissa) as young fish and back to the sea for breeding in June/July. This species is esteemed as a food fish. The maximum size attained is 150 cm; common size 45-60 cm. The airbladders are made into rough isinglass; marketed mostly fresh.

Lates calcarifer is one of  northern Australia's most important commercial fish species and is one of the most popular angling species (Allen et al. 2002). It is of huge commercial importance throughout its range as it is a very good tasting fish and it grows quickly (Larson 1999). Because of its high economic importance and commercial value, it is heavily aquacultured throughout its range, with most production in Southeast Asia, generally from small coastal cage farms. Often these farms will culture a mixture of species, including Barramundi, groupers (Family Serranidae, Subfamily Epinephelinae) and snappers (Family Lutjanidae).

Australia is experiencing the development of large-scale Barramundi farms that reflect the industrialized style of aquaculture seen in Europe. Where Barramundi farming is undertaken outside the tropics, recirculation production systems are often used (e.g. in southern Australia and in the north-eastern United States of America).

Barramundi has been introduced for aquaculture purposes to Iran, Guam, French Polynesia, the United States of America (Hawaii, Massachusetts) and Israel (FAO Fisheries and Aquaculture Fact Sheet).

It is also commercially fished throughout its range, mostly with gillnets (Larson 1999) and with rod-and-reel in recreational sport fishing (Larson 1999). Until 1990, less than 20,000 tonnes were harvested yearly, but by 1993, the landings totals doubled to over 40,000 tonnes per year. By the year 2,000, the total landings had increased to 75,000 tonnes and in 2010, the global landings had increased to over 100,000 tonnes (FAO Fisheries Statistics). 

In The Gulf, Pakistan reported landing 600 tonnes of  L. calcarifer and reaching 3,018 tonnes in 1982. However, in subsequent years, Pakistan's landing steadily decreased until 1999, when it reported landing just over 200 tonnes, and then Pakistan did not report landing any more of this species (FishStatJ Global Capture Statistics). Indonesia reports landing the most tonnage of this fish by far, reporting landing 12,438 tonnes in the East Indian Ocean and 85,257 tonnes from the Western-Central Pacific (FishStatJ Global Capture Statistics).
conservationActions:
Research into the species' taxonomy is suggested as this may be a species complex.

Stocks are managed in northern Australia for both recreational and commercial fishing.

rationale:
Global

Diplodus vulgaris is a common and widespread species ranging from the Bay of Biscay to the Mediterranean and the coast of Africa, occurring to depths of 160 m. There is no evidence of population declines, despite its high commercial value. The range of D. vulgaris overlaps with marine protected areas throughout its range. It is therefore listed as Least Concern. 

Europe

This species is widespread and abundant in European waters. Its range also overlaps with a number of marine protected areas in the region. It is therefore listed as Least Concern.
habitat:
This is a euryhaline species inhabiting particularly rocky and sandy bottoms usually close to Posidonia oceanica plants to depths of 160 m, but more commonly in less than 50 m and sometimes in lagoons (Arculeo et al. 2003, Carpenter in prep). The young are sometimes found in seagrass beds (Carpenter in press). Food items are mainly composed of algae, bivalves and crustaceans. Diplodus vulgaris shows a generalist feeding behaviour and is omnivorous (Horta et al. 2004). 

The spawning season for D. vulgaris in southern Portugal extends from September to April, with a length at 50% maturity of 17.27 cm for males and 17.65 cm for females (Gonçalves et al. 2003). The spawning season for this species off the southwest coast of Portugal was reported to extend from December to March, peaking in January and February. This species is characterized as a rudimentary hermaphrodite with possible protandry (Gonçalves and Erizini 2000). 

In the western Mediterranean Sea, this species is a hermaphrodite and its reproduction occurs in autumn , the young are present in December-January and the older fish in May-June. Sexual maturity occurs at two years of age between 17 and 19 cm length (Fischer et al. 1987, Dulcic et al. 2010). The parameters of the Von Bertalanffy growth model for this species are: L∞ =28.78 cm, K=0.389, to=-0.657 (Gordoa and Moli 1997); L∞=26.77 cm, K=0.255, to=-0.607 (Man-Wai and Quignard 1984); and L∞.=23.47 cm, K=0.224, to=-1.446 (Bradai 2000). The maximum total length of this species is 45 cm (Fischer et al. 1987) and its longevity was reported as eight years (Bradai 2000); however, Dragičević et al. (unpublished 2007) reported that the maximum age of this species exceeds 20 years. 

Generation length for D. vulgaris is estimated to be nine years, using the following equation for a gonochoristic fish species: Generation length = Σxlxmx/Σlxmx
threats: Potential localized declines from fishing and habitat modification pose a threat to D. vulgaris.
population:
Diplodus vulgaris is common outside sea-cage forms in the Turkish Aegean Sea, feeding on the feed (pellets) (Akyol and Ertosluk 2010), and accounted for 2.7% of the total weight around one fish farm from 2004–2008. There is significant genetic variation between populations of D. vulgaris in the Aegean and Adriatic Seas (Arculeo et al. 2003). 

This species is common and abundant throughout the Mediterranean Sea. It is common along the West African coast from the Straits of Gibraltar to Cape Verde, around Madeira and the Canary Islands (Carpenter in press).

The catch statistics for Turkey were: 1995 - 2,152 tonnes, 1996 - 1,889 tonnes, 1997 - 1,250 tonnes, 1998 - 1,500 tonnes, 1999 -1,560 tonnes, 2001- 375 tonnes, 2002 - 203 tonnes, and 2006 - 185 tonnes. An average of 16% of the Turkish catch comes from the Black Sea.

FAO capture production figures for 2012 were: Croatia - 15 tonnes, Cyprus - five tonnes, Malta - one tonne, and Portugal - 367 tonnes.
range: Diplodus vulgaris is present in the eastern Atlantic from southwestern France (Bay of Biscay) to Senegal, including Madeira and the Canary Islands, but is absent from the Cape Verde Islands (Carpenter in press). It is present throughout the Mediterranean Sea and in the southern Black Sea. The records from Angola to South Africa (Carpenter in press) need to be verified (Smith and Smith 1986). This species occurs to 160 m depth (Sala and Ballesteros 1997).
useTrade:
Fishing for this species is semi-industrial (in Sicily, the Adriatic and Egypt) and artisanal elsewhere, and it is also a sport fish.  The main fishing gears are trammel nets, gill nets, hand lines, traps (Canary Islands), beach seines (young fish), bottom long lines and spear fishing. This species is usually present in the markets of Sicily, Italy, Spain, Turkey, Greece, Cyprus, Tunisia, Morocco, France and countries in the Adriatic Sea. Marketed fresh, frozen or dried salted (its flesh is not very highly esteemed) and is also used for fishmeal and oil (Carpenter in press).

Species of Diplodus, including D. vulgaris, are highly valuable resources in Portugal. In 2008, together they were the 13th most important item in the landings, and the 11th in terms of commercialized value (Instituto Nacional De Estatística 2009), and this genus was the sixth most important fish species in the landings in 2000, averaging 57% of the national catches in weight from 1988 to 2000 (DGPA 2002, Gonclaves et al. 2003). Official data and management does not regard these species as individual units, and data are collected on the Diplodus genus in general, which is an important limitation for scientific studies and proper management (Vinagre et al. 2010).

Diplodus vulgaris is a candidate for aquaculture as it has a high tolerance for low salinity and can mature easily without hormone treatment (Jug-Dujakovic and  Glamuzina 1988, Horta et al. 2004, Ozório et al. 2009).
conservationActions: The minimum landing size for this species in Portugal is 15 cm (Gonçalves et al. 2003). It occurs in several marine protected areas within its range (World Database of Protected Areas, accessed 11 March 2014). It is recommended that more genetic research be conducted for the management of this species.

rationale: This species is restricted to the southern half of California and the northern Gulf of California, and is considered common throughout its range. Coastal development within its range may pose a threat to this species. Although there is no current indication of widespread population decline, this species and its habitat should be carefully monitored. It is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This species inhabits bays and coastal sloughs, burrowing in shallow mud substrate in tidal flats and bays including coastal lagoons and river mouths. This species can tolerate a wide range of salinity (Miller et al. 2005).
threats: Coastal development in lagoons and esturaries, such as marinas and aquaculture, is the most serious threat to this species. Coastal pollution of heavy metals and metalloids from mining operations and nutrient and pesticide runoff from intensive agricultural and pond aquaculture, including associated harmful algal blooms (HABs) have been documented in the Gulf of California (Paez-Osuna et al. 2017). However, the impacts of these environmental pollutants require further research. In San Francisco Bay, environmental pollutants have been linked to increased adult mortality and reduced growth (McGourty et al. 2009).
population: Total population size and population trend are unknown. However, this species is common to abundant in suitable habitat within its range (L. Findley pers. comm. 2007). In La Paz Bay, Baja California Sur, this species is reported as rare (Gonzalez-Acosta et al. 2005).
range: This species is endemic to the Eastern Pacific and is found from north central California southward to Magdalena Bay, and in the northern Gulf of California southwest to Mulege and southeast into Agiabampo Bay (Balart et al. 1997, Miller et al. 2005). The close congener G. detrusus replaces this species in the lowermost Colorado River and the Colorado River delta (Swift et al. 2011).
conservationActions: There are no known conservation measures for this species. However, the range of this species includes multiple protected areas (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2019). More information regarding distribution, population size and trend, life history and ecology, and the impacts of potential threats would be useful in guiding future conservation action.

rationale: Morone chrysops has been assessed as Least Concern. This species has a broad distribution across the United States and Canada and occupies a range of habitat types. It has expanded its range and is increasing in abundance in areas. There are no known major threats reportedly impacting the population of this species, and therefore the population of this species is reported to be stable.
habitat: This species is known from a range of habitat types including the open waters of large lakes and reservoirs, to the pools of slow-moving small and large rivers. This species is typically seen in schools at the water surface. During the day this species is seen offshore in the open waters of the lake, and at night it moves inshore. It displays an avoidance for areas of continuous turbidity. Spawning grounds are usually in the running water of tributary streams with rock or gravel substrate, or along lake shores with high wave action. Individuals tend to return to specific spawning grounds.
threats: There are no known major threats thought to be causing a significant decline in the population numbers of this species. In some areas of its range, it is under pressure for resources due to competition with the invasive species Morone americana. This species is also fished recreationally, however this does not appear to pose a significant threat to this species as it is described as growing in abundance in areas and expanding its range.
population:
This species is represented by a large number of occurrences (subpopulations): Total adult population size is unknown but presumably exceeds 1,000,000.

Abundance has increased in the lower Missouri River as a result of human-caused changes in the river (e.g. reservoir construction and consequent reductions in turbidity) (Pflieger and Grace 1987).

Warren et al. (2000) categorized the trend as "currently stable" in the southeastern United States.
range: This species is native to the St. Lawrence-Great Lakes, Hudson Bay (Red River), and Mississippi River basins from Quebec to Manitoba and south to Louisiana; Gulf Slope drainages from Mississippi River, Louisiana, to Rio Grande, Texas and New Mexico (Page and Burr 1991). It has been introduced widely within and outside its natural range.
conservationActions: Currently, this species is of relatively low conservation concern and does not require significant additional protection or major management, monitoring, or research action.

rationale:
Global Assessment: This is a widespread species that is locally abundant with no well-documented major threats across its entire range and is therefore considered Least Concern. However, because of its shallow depth distribution and potential for impacts from coastal development and pollution, particularly because of its inability to move away from its home range, further research is needed to monitor this species.

European Regional Assessment: Lipophrys pholis is found in the northeastern Atlantic Ocean, including the western Mediterranean Sea. It is a widespread species that is locally abundant. There are no well-documented major threats across its entire range, and the population seems to be stable. Therefore L. pholis is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: This is a resident intertidal species with homing behaviour (Gibson 1999) found in shallow waters of rocky coasts. It may remain out of water under rocks or seaweeds (Martin and Bridges 1999), and is mostly active at daytime during high tide. This species feeds on small benthic invertebrates, especially gastropods, barnacles, amphipods, and algae. It breathes air when out of water (Martin and Bridges 1999). Spawning takes place in April - August (Muus and Nielsen 1999). Male guards eggs from several females (Zander 1986).
threats: It is a shallow water species and therefore could be impacted by coastal development and pollution. It is particularly sensitive to organic pollution (Lima et al. 2008) and is likely to be heavily threatened in very restricted areas. However, there is no current evidence that this constitutes a major threat for this species across its range.
population: This is a common and locally abundant species in tide pools along the northeastern Atlantic coast (Nieder 1993, Faria and Almada 1999, Lima et al. 2008).
range: Lipophrys pholis is found in the eastern Atlantic from southern Norway to Morocco and Madeira, including Macaronesia (Almada et al. 2001). It is also found in the western Mediterranean to the Balearic Islands (Zander 1986). Lipophrys pholis has been recorded from 0-8 m (Zander 1986).
useTrade: This species can thrive in marine aquariums. It can also be used as an indicator species for pollution monitoring because of its abundance, restricted home range, inability to move away from its home range if impacted by threats, and sensitivity to organic contaminants (Lima et al. 2008).
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this species, but it is widespread and likely occurs in protected areas.

rationale: This widely distributed species is common where it occurs on oyster reefs and other shallow structured areas. There are no known major threats. Therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This estuarine species can be found in association with oyster reefs (takes shelter in empty shells) as well as grassy and rocky shallow areas, around pilings, or in rocky tide pools (Runyan 1961, Tolley and Volety 2005, McEachran and Fechhelm 2005). Beck (2012) found that this species is strongly associated with the number of live oysters and the amount of oyster clusters. It appears to prefer the larger interstitial spaces offered by clusters and likely feeds upon the basal consumers abundant in areas where oysters provide benthopelagic coupling services. Beck (2012) also found that a higher percentage of individuals are larger in unharvested reefs than in harvested reefs. It can be found in Zostera marina beds in the lower Chesapeake bay (Orth and Heck, Jr. 1980). It utilizes a ventral, adhesive disc to attachment to relatively stable objects like oyster shells, pilings, rocks, and loggerhead sponges (Runyan 1961). It usually occurs in water less than one metre deep, but sometimes to 33 m (Smith 1997). It has been reared in captivity and development has been well documented (Moe 1992). The eggs are laid in empty oyster shells and tended by adults (Runyan 1961). Adults are usually male and eggs in good condition are generally found with a male that is keeping them constantly aerated by fanning them with their anal and caudal fins (Ruck 1971). It hosts the parasitic acanthocephala Floridosentis elongatus (Williams, Jr. and Gaines, Jr.1974) and marine leeches (Sawyer and Hammond 1973).
threats: One of its preferred habitats is oyster reefs, which are in serious decline across North America due to disease and overharvesting. However, this species adapts well to other habitats including disturbed habitats, and therefore, this is not considered to be a major overall threat.
population: This species can be common in parts of its range. It has been frequently collected on oyster reefs of the Caloosahatchee estuary in southwest Florida (Tolley and Volety 2005, Tolley et al. 2005). It was the fifth most abundant species collected from a marsh-edge nekton community in Louisiana (Roth and Baltz 2009).
range: This species is distributed in the western Atlantic from New Jersey south along the U.S. coast, Bermuda, throughout the Gulf of Mexico, and in the Caribbean from northern Cuba and Quintana Roo, Mexico to western Honduras (R. Robertson pers. comm. 2014). It is absent from the Bahamas. In the  Eastern Central Pacific, this species can be found in the  coastal lagoons and tidal flats of Sonora, Sinaloa and Nayarit, Mexico.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place.

rationale: Abudefduf saxatilis is widespread in the tropical Atlantic Ocean. It is the most common and abundant damselfish throughout its range. There are no major  threats identified and it is found in a number of marine reserves in parts of its range. It is therefore assessed as Least Concern.
habitat:
This species is reef-associated and non-migratory. Juveniles of this species are common in tide pools and raft with drifting Sargassum and other floating objects (L.A. Rocha and R.F. Myers pers. comm. 2010); adults are found over shallow reef tops. Adults frequently form large feeding aggregations of up to several hundred individuals. Food items include algae, small crustaceans and fish, and various invertebrate larvae (Carter 2002). At Fernando de Noronha Archipelago, this species feeds on spinner dolphins’ faeces and vomits. The offal feeding may be regarded as a simple behavioural shift from plankton feeding to drifting offal picking. Also, juveniles may hold cleaning stations together with the Doctorfish (Acanthurus chirurgus) and the Blue Tang (Acanthurus coeruleus) and graze algae as well as pick moulted skin and parasites from Green Turtles (Chelonia mydas). This behaviour is preceded by a characteristic inspection usually followed by feeding nips on the turtles’ skin (head, limbs, and tail), as well as on the carapace. The most inspected and cleaned body parts are the flippers (Sazima et al. 2003).

It is a territorial species. Adult males adopt a bluish ground colour when guarding eggs. They are attracted to divers who feed fish and are marketed fresh (Emery 1978). This species has been reared in captivity (Moe 1992). Abudefduf saxatilis reaches first maturity at 12 cm (Xavier et al. 2012). It is oviparous, displaying distinct pairing during breeding. Its eggs are demersal and adhere to the substrate. Males guard and aerate the eggs (Thresher 1984). In transition zones, A. saxatilis is often the most populous and sometimes the sole omnivore. It utilizes shallow reef habitats for nursery grounds (Xavier et al. 2012). There is statistical evidence that this species of fish provides ontological connectivity between mangrove habitats and reef habitats, as juvenile individuals of A. saxatilis inhabit both mangrove forests and reefs and adult individuals migrate to or stay at reef habitats (Jones et al. 2010). It prefers reef structures with lower exposure and higher non-consolidated substratum cover (Krajewski and Floeter 2011).
threats: This species is a component of subsistence fisheries and is incidentally caught in the aquarium trade. It has been identified as a prey item of the invasive Lionfish (Pterois volitans), however, only juveniles are consumed and it is not likely that this will drive significant population declines on a global level (Valdez-Moreno et al. 2012, L.A. Rocha pers. comm. 2014).
population: This species is the most common and widespread species of damselfish in the Atlantic. It is common off Mexico in the Gulf of Mexico (M. Vega-Cendejas pers. comm. 2013). Surveys found its abundance increased by 210% in St. Croix, 78% in St. John, and 61% in Puerto Rico from 2011 abundances (NOAA NCCOS 2010). In the Mamanguape Environmental Protection Area in NE Brazil, this species was one of the most abundant of fishes in the reef zones (Xavier et al. 2012). Abudefduf saxatilis comprised 1.7% of all fish species in reef fish assemblages off Havana City, Cuba (Gonzalez-Sanson and Aguilar 2010). In reef fish assemblages off northwest Cuba, A. saxatilis accounts for 3.2% of the total fish population and has a frequency of occurrence in the area of 66.7% (Gonzalez-Sanson et al. 2009).
range:
This species is distributed in the tropical Atlantic Ocean. In the western Atlantic, it is known from North Carolina south along the U.S. coast, Bermuda, the Bahamas, throughout the Gulf of Mexico and Caribbean Sea to Trinidad including the Aves Islands, and along the Brazilian coast from Sao Luis to Santa Catarina including the San Fernando de Noronha Islands, St. Paul's Rocks, and Trinidade Island (Lubbock and Edwards 1981, Feitoza et al. 2003, Simon et al. 2013). Seasonal juveniles have been reported as far north as Rhode Island and far south as Uruguay (R.F. Myers pers. comm. 2010). In the eastern Atlantic, it is known from the Cape Verde Islands south along western Africa to Angola, including all mid-Atlantic oceanic islands.

It is replaced in the Indo-Pacific region by the closely related Abudefduf vaigiensis (G. Allen pers. comm. 2010).
useTrade: This species is a component of subsistence fisheries. It is caught incidentally in the aquarium trade. The species is extremely hardy (indicating tolerance to a wide range of water and temperature regimes).
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this fish.

rationale: Atractosteus spatula has a large distribution from central and southeastern United States to eastern Mexico, Nicaragua and northwestern Costa Rica. The species is uncommon to rare in most of its range but abundant enough to support fisheries in some areas. Local population declines have been observed as a result of overfishing, habitat degradation from river channelization and impoundments, loss of spawning habitat and loss of passages between main river channels and floodplains.While it is declining in parts of its range, it is not thought that any global population decline is likely to meet (or be close to meeting) the threshold for Vulnerable. Therefore the species is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: This gar is one of the largest freshwater fishes in North America, attaining sizes of up to 3 m and 300 pounds. Eats mostly fishes and crabs and occasionally other small vertebrates. Habitat includes sluggish pools of large rivers and their bayous, oxbow lakes, swamps, and backwaters, brackish and marine waters along the coast (Page & Burr 2011).
threats:
This species is known to destroy gillnets and trawls in both freshwater and estuarine habitats (O'Connell et al. 2007). As a result, fishing pressure, habitat alteration, and active management to remove all gar species as nuisance fishes has reduced A. spatula populations throughout its range, including Oklahoma, Texas, Alabama, Mississippi, and Florida (Gilbert 1992, Scarnecchia 1992, Ross et al. 2001, Aguilera et al. 2002).

This species is threatened by habitat loss and degradation from urban and agricultural runoff, shell dredging, over-fishing, artificial saltwater and freshwater inputs, shoreline alteration, and industrial discharges (O'Connell et al. 2007). Factors such as fragmentation of river-floodplain corridors, impoundments, channelisation and urbanisation have likely impacted Atractosteus spatula populations, especially as the population of Texas expands and water demands increase, reducing connectivity of river channels to backwater spawning and nursery areas, and affect estuarine habitats by increasing salinity (Buckmeier, 2008).
The species is also threatened by recreational and commercial fishing in parts of its range (Garcia de Leon et al. 2001; Aguilera et al. 2002).
Natural introgression with sympatric Lepisosteus osseus and L. oculatus may threaten this species, especially in areas with depressed population abundances (Bohn et al. 2017).
population: Total population size is unknown but presumably exceeds 10,000 to > 1,000,000 individuals (Hammerson, 2004). Atractosteus spatula is uncommon to rare throughout most of the range, except locally in swamps and bayous of the south-central United States (Page & Burr 2011) and the brackish waters of the Gulf of Mexico where it is frequently seen (Hoese & Moore, 1998). Area of occupancy and abundance have declined over the long term, particularly in the northern part of the range. The degree of decline is uncertain but likely exceeds 30 percent (Hammerson, 2004).
range: Atractosteus spatula global range is estimated to cover 200,000-2,500,000 square km (Hammerson, 2004). Historical range included the Mississippi River basin in the USA, from southwestern Ohio (Trautman 1981), southern Indiana, and southern Illinois (Smith 1979) to the Gulf of Mexico; also the Gulf Coastal Plain from the Florida panhandle (Gilbert 1992) to Veracruz, Mexico, with disjunct occurrences in Nicaragua and northwestern Costa Rica (Lee et al. 1980). Now the species is extirpated or very rare in most of the northern part of its range north of the Gulf Coastal Plain (Hammerson, 2004).
useTrade: Common as a market fish in Louisiana and numerous enough to support a gillnet fishery in a reservoir in Tamualipas, Mexico (Garcia de Leon et al. 2001).
conservationActions:
In recent years management efforts have changed from attempts to limit or exterminate gar populations to conserving whole aquatic ecosystems, and there is also growing interest to manage Atractosteus spatula as both a game species (e.g., bow hunting in particular; Ross et al. 2001) and a commercial species (Garcia de Leon et al. 2001).

There are also some preliminary attempts to examine the possibility of culturing Atractosteus spatula as an aquaculture species or at least to use hatchery techniques to augment declining natural populations (Aguilera et al. 2002).

rationale: This species is widely distributed and is often very locally abundant. It can be harvested particularly by commercial, recreational or artisanal fishers in most areas but typically in relatively small numbers. It is one of the most common shallow reef fishes in the Greater Caribbean. There are no known major threats at the global scale. It is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: Haemulon flavolineatum occurs in large schools on rocky and coral reefs to depths of 60 m. This species settles in shallow waters in a variety of structural habitat types including hardbottom and vegetated habitats. Juveniles exhibit a pattern of diel migration from protective resting sites on coral reefs during the day to night-time feeding grounds of seagrass beds and other soft bottom habitats such as sand and mud (Ogden and Ehrlich 1977). Juveniles school during the day at coral reef and other hard bottom habitats then disperse around dusk to feed solitarily throughout the night (Helfman et al. 1982). Dispersal distances for juveniles are suspected to range from tens to hundreds of metres (Ogden and Ehrlich 1977), although few direct measurements of this distance have been conducted. A study on the pattern of habitat utilization in H. flavolineatum by Kendall et al. (2003) indicated that both juvenile and adult were found primarily over hard bottom substrates during the day. Juveniles were primarily found in lagoon areas as indicated by Ogden and Erlich (1977). However, adults were also more likely to be found in lagoons, not offshore as was previously speculated (Ogden and Erlich 1977). Juveniles can show fidelity to daytime sites across periods between 47 and 425 days, even though these sites are located in extensive and spatially continuous back-reef habitats. Furthermore, part of the population sheltering in shoreline shelter habitats (mangroves and rocky shoreline) during daytime move to adjacent seagrass beds in the afternoon (after 11:45am), likely to start feeding in seagrasses during daylight. Populations probably continue feeding here during night time, away from the daytime shelter sites, but in the morning of the next day, most fishes return to exactly the same shoreline shelter sites as those of the previous day (Verweij and Nagelkerken 2007). Pelagic larval duration lasts an average of 14 days (Brothers and McFarland 1981, McFarland et al. 1985) at which time larvae settle into sand or seagrass habitats (Shulman 1985a) or onto reef structures (McFarland et al. 1985) and begin their benthic life. Juveniles in seagrass or sand habitats migrate to reefs within first month of settlement (Shulman 1985). Seagrass beds are an important nursery biotype for juveniles of this species but appear to utilize mangrove and seagrass nursery biotypes simultaneously (Nagelkerken et al. 2000). In the Caribbean, grunts usually settle into seagrass beds, then move onto reefs several weeks later (McFarland 1979). They also can settle abundantly on hardbottom habitats in shallower depth zones (Lindeman and Snyder 1999, Jordan et al. 2012). In Barbados, seagrass beds are scarce, and grunt juveniles generally settle directly onto reefs (Tupper 1989). Newly settled grunts remain closely associated with the substrate for one to two weeks, but as they grow they forage farther from the reef (Tupper and Juanes 1999). Food items include plankton from settlement until 3-4 cm (SL), then benthic invertebrates for adults (Helfman et al. 1982, McFarland pers. comm. in Shulman and Ogden 1987). Mangroves and seagrass beds provide daytime feeding habitats for some life-stages of H. flavolineatum, which is generally considered a nocturnal feeder (Verweij et al. 2006). The juvenile usage of several backreef habitats in comparison to congeners is reviewed in Nagelkerken (2009). Sexual maturity is attained at 12-15 cm (SL) (Billings and Munro 1974). Spawning has not been observed in this species and spawning behaviours and frequencies are not known (Shulman and Ogden 1987). However, spawning has been reported throughout the year off Jamaica and in the northeastern Caribbean, where individuals in spawning condition have been observed in March and September (Erdman 1976, NMFS 2005). In a portion of Tague Bay, St. Croix, U.S. Virgin Islands, mean annual recruitment was recorded at 1.8 recruits per m2 of lagoon floor, equivalent to 44 recruits per m2 of juvenile habitat per year and among the highest recruitment rates reported for reef fishes. Post-settlement mortality was also very high: during the first month of benthic life it was 0.9 and during the first year was >0.992 (Shulman and Ogden 1987). Recruits can distinguish between water types from different habitats and show a preference for water from seagrass beds and mangroves over that from the coral reef (Huijbers et al. 2008). Maximum total length for this species is 30 cm (Robins and Ray 1986).
threats: Due to the absence of directed fisheries and the exceptional frequency and abundance of this species, there are few major direct threats to this species. A study conducted by Hawkins and Roberts (2004) to determine the effects of artisanal fishing to fish assemblages and benthic communities in six islands in the Caribbean (where fishing pressures ranged from non-existent in Bonaire to very high intensities in Jamaica) showed grunt biomass did not decrease as fishing pressure increased, although biomass differed significantly among the islands. It has been identified as a prey item of the invasive Lionfish, Pterois volitans (Valdez-Moreno et al. 2012, Green and Cote 2014). Adults of the species are closely associated with corals and a variety of direct and indirect threats may arise with increasing climate change impacts on corals and associated habitats (Ateweberhan et al. 2013).
population: Haemulon flavolineatum is very abundant in many parts of its range. Several of many examples follow. Haemulon flavolineatum was the second most abundant species to colonize artificial reefs within the Looe Key Special Protected Area from May 2001 to August 2002 (Peterson et al. 2013). This species is very common off many areas of Mexico (M. Vega-Cendejas pers. comm. 2013). This species was the most frequently encountered grunt, occurring in 35% of the total surveys, and represented the greatest grunt biomass inside the Virgin Island Coral Reef National Monument (VICRNM) (Monaco et al. 2007). At the VICRNM, mean H. flavolineatum biomass was 27% greater outside compared with inside from 2002-2004. It is the most abundant species recorded in Lamarka Reef, Nicaragua (WWF USAID-CAFTA 2009) and is also very abundant in Venezuela (Cervigon 1993). French Grunt was one of five species that accounted for 77% of visual census density of trappable fish in the Barbados Marine Reserve and adjacent non-reserve area. Density estimates recorded for this species were 23.17 individuals/400 m2 in the Barbados Marine Reserve and 9.70 individuals/400 m2 outside the reserve (Chapman and Kramer 1999). A study by Tupper and Juanes (1999) on the effects of the Barbados Marine Reserve on the recruitment dynamics of haemulid fishes and their predators on coral reefs, showed that size and abundance of adult grunts (Haemulon chrysargyreum, H. aurolineatum and H. flavolineatum) and piscivores that prey on grunts were greater within the reserve than on adjacent reefs. Size and abundance of older juvenile grunts did not differ between protected and exploited reefs. Recruitment and early juvenile abundance were lower within the reserve and were inversely related to predator density.
range: Haemulon flavolineatum is distributed in the western Atlantic from South Carolina south along the U.S. coast, Bermuda, the Bahamas, in the Gulf of Mexico from the Florida Keys and from Tuxpan, Mexico along the northern Yucatan to northwestern Cuba, and throughout the Caribbean to Trinidad. Records from Brazil are based on misidentifications. Its depth range is one to 60 m.
useTrade: Due to its abundance, this species can be exploited in local fisheries. However, due to its small size, it is typically not sought in a directed manner. It can be caught by hook and line, trap and seine. It is one of the most common commercially exploited fishes on Barbados reefs (Tupper and Juanes 1999). It is marketed fresh (Courtenay and Sahlman 1978, Robins and Ray 1986). Occasionally it appears in the aquarium trade.
conservationActions:
Effective April 2012, this species was removed from the Snapper-Grouper fishery management unit of the US South Atlantic Fishery Management Council and it is not managed in the federal waters of the US Gulf of Mexico. It is included in the Reef Fish Management Plan of the US Caribbean Fishery Management Council, where landings are allocated by commercial and recreational sectors for mixed haemulids. The species is not directly managed in most countries. 

This species can occur within marine protected areas (MPAs) of variable effectiveness. Results from Tupper and Juanes (1999) on grunt recruitment within and outside of an MPA in Barbados indicate that although protection had a significant positive effect on the size and abundance of large carnivorous fishes, higher predation inside the reserve may lead to reduced juvenile recruitment.

rationale: The Banded Kokopu (Galaxias fasciatus) is a large, amphidromous galaxiiid endemic to New Zealand. Historically, this species has undergone substantial declines in range and abundance, primarily due to the loss and degradation of adult habitat. The population is now considered relatively stable and the species is widespread and locally abundant throughout much of its range. It is is one of five species that occur in the whitebait runs each spring and is a significant component of the national whitebait fishery. Although several common causes of decline have been implicated in the general range contraction and decrease in abundance of large galaxiids (including over harvesting of the juvenile whitebait stage, artificial barriers to migration, habitat destruction, pollution of waterways, changes in catchment land use and the impacts of introduced species), this species is widespread and the population is now considered stable. It was covered within the New Zealand Department of Conservation's large galaxiid recovery plan 2003-2013. However, it is listed as 'Not Threatened' in the national Department of Conservation's listings and is considered of low conservation priority with no species specific actions required. Considering the stabilization of population trend along with the plasticity in life history (ability to form land locked or marine derived populations, plus high recruitment capabilities), this species is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: G. fasciatus is a large, amphidromous galaxiid (with females reaching up to 300 mm in length), which also readily forms land-locked populations in lakes. It is typically found at low-mid elevations in pools of small forested streams where there is good cover from overhanging vegetation, banks, boulders and woody debris (McDowall 1990). Males mature at 2 years of age while females mature at 4 years (Hopkins 1979a,b). Specimens are commonly found up to 200 mm (McDowall 1990), which are likely to be about 7 years of age based on average growth rates (Hopkins 1979a). This is likely to be the typical intergeneration time of this species, assuming this is the common adult length and growth rate. G. fasciatus can often reach up to 260 mm (McDowall 1990), which are likely to be around 10 years old. Individuals are however likely to reach older ages given that West et al. (2005) found one specimen that may have been up to 15 years of age. This is the oldest known specimen and is likely to be close to the maximum lifespan of this species. Spawning occurs from autumn/early winter close to typical adult habitats. Eggs have been observed to be deposited terrestrially during high water events, hatching after re-inundation (Mitchell and Penlington 1982). Larvae rear in estuaries or at sea and return to freshwater after 4-6 months as whitebait. This species is a skilled climber at whitebait stage and is able to migrate up substantial waterfalls (NIWA 2013, Mitchell and Penlington, 1982). Like other large galaxiids, G. fasciatus feeds primarily opportunistically on terrestrial and aquatic invertebrates and occasionally feeding on small fish (West et al. 2005, Department of Conservation 2005, McDowall 2000).
threats: Several common causes of decline have been implicated in the general range contraction and decrease in abundance of large galaxiids. These include overharvesting of the juvenile whitebait stage, artificial barriers to migration, habitat destruction, pollution of waterways, changes in catchment land use and the impacts of introduced species (Department of Conservation 2005). The primary threat to this species is thought to be the loss and degradation of adult habitat through deforestation and other land use changes, which have impacted their preferred native forest stream habitats. Loss of wetlands is also likely to have negatively affected the distribution of this species. It is considered that partial obstruction and/or complete loss of fish passage due to artificial barriers (particularly undercut culverts and hydro dams that disrupt river connectivity and access to adult habitats), in many regions has also negatively affected the distribution of this species. There is a potential threat of predation and competition by introduced salmonids, primarily Brown Trout (Salmo trutta). Furthermore, the loss of riparian vegetation impacts on spawning success, is likely to change water temperatures and reduce the availability of terrestrial food supply (Department of Conservation 2005, McDowall 2000).
population: Historically, the population of this species has undergone substantial declines in range and abundance, particularly in developed areas such as the Manawatu and Canterbury plains (with loss of habitat through forest clearance) and with the introduction of invasive predatory fish species (such as Brown Trout (Salmo trutta)). Currently, there is a gap in the distribution of this species, between Banks Peninsula and Otago Peninsula on the east coast, but this is probably due to a lack of typical habitat. However, it is widespread and locally abundant throughout the rest of its range and the population is now considered relatively stable (McDowall 2000, Allibone et al. 2010, NIWA 2013).
range: The Banded Kokopu (Galaxias fasciatus) is endemic to New Zealand including North and South Islands, Stewart, Chatham and many offshore islands around the main islands, but not the sub-Antarctic islands (McDowall 1990, NZFFD 2011).
useTrade: This species is one of five species that occur in the whitebait runs each spring and is a significant component of the national whitebait fishery (NIWA 2013, Department of Conservation 2005, McDowall, 1984).
conservationActions: This species was covered within the New Zealand Department of Conservation's large galaxiid recovery plan 2003-2013 (Department of Conservation 2005), however it is listed as nationally Not Threatened according to the New Zealand Department of Conservation's threat classification system (Goodman et al. 2014) and is considered of low conservation priority, with no species specific actions required.

rationale: The Crans Bully (Gobiomorhous basalis) is endemic to the North Island of New Zealand where it is widely distributed throughout inland areas with the exception of the volcanic plateau. This species appears to be tolerant of wide range of conditions from partially degraded through to pristine habitats and is found in streams and rivers with mixed substrate types. It is very abundant in spring creeks and also low to medium gradient streams with moderate flow. As it is non-migratory with no requirement to reach the sea, this species is commonly found at mid-altitude sites and at some distance inland. As this species has no marine phase, its ability to colonize new river systems is limited and once it has been lost from an area, it is unlikely it will recolonise on its own. Site-specific loss of larval backwater spawning and rearing habitats through channelisation and possibly water abstraction are potential threats to this species. However, the population is considered stable and is nationally considered 'Not Threatened'. Considering its wide distribution in a number of habitats and stable population trend, this species is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: G. basalis is found in streams and rivers with mixed substrate types. It is very abundant in spring creeks and also low to medium gradient streams with moderate flow. This species is non-migratory and is commonly found at mid-altitude sites and at some distance inland (NIWA 2013). This species appears to be tolerant of wide range of conditions from partially degraded through to pristine habitats. G. basalis lives to 8 years, maturing at 1 year with a generation time of 4 years (McDowall, 2000). Adults spawn in spring and summer. Males establish a territory beneath a rock where the female deposits eggs in a single layer, which the male probably guards. Several hundred eggs are laid, which hatch after several weeks and larvae rear in stream margins and backwaters (McDowall 2000).
threats: Site-specific loss of larval backwater spawning and rearing habitats through channelization and possibly water abstraction are potential threats to this species. As this species has no marine phase, its ability to colonize new river systems is limited and once they have gone from an area, it is unlikely they will recolonize on their own (NIWA 2013).
population: The population is generally considered stable and the species can be locally abundant in certain areas (NZFFD 2011).
range: The Crans Bully (Gobiomorhous basalis) is endemic to the North Island of New Zealand, where it is distributed throughout inland areas of the North Island with the exception of the volcanic plateau (McDowall 1990).
conservationActions: There are no specific conservation actions in place for this species and it is nationally listed as 'Not Threatened' according the New Zealand Department of Conservation's threat classification system (Goodman et al. 2014).

rationale: The Common Bully (Gobiomorphus cotidanus) is endemic to New Zealand where it is found throughout the main North and South Islands, Stewart Island and near offshore islands such as Great Barrier Island. It is facultatively diadromous meaning it can rear in lentic and lotic freshwater or marine environments. This relatively large freshwater fish is often seen at total length of 120 mm. It is a benthic species that reach 4-5 years of age, maturing at 1 year and with a generation time of 2 years. Several hundred to a few thousand eggs are laid during spawning (which occurs annually) and the territorial male guards the nest site. This species is widespread and abundant throughout its range, however presence absence records have indicated around a 25% decline over the past 12 years from river and stream habitats (but these data excludes lake habitats). Habitats are likely to be impacted by water abstraction, agricultural development and land use changes and this species is also a major prey item of introduced salmoniids, particularly Brown Trout (Salmo trutta). However, as it is present and abundant in a number of large water bodies and a variety of habitats, it is not considered to be significantly threatened by these processes. Additionally, G. cotidanus exhibits tolerance to highly eutrophic conditions and is considered 'Not Threatened' nationally, according to the New Zealand Department of Conservation's threat classification system. Although there is a possible population reduction over parts of its range, this species is widespread and abundant and has been assessed as considered Least Concern. Monitoring of populations would be valuable to identify whether the entire population is truly declining and if so what the causes of decline are attributed to.
habitat: G. cotidanus is facultatively diadromous, meaning it can rear in lentic and lotic freshwater or marine environments. It prefers aquatic habitats with a slow to moderate rate of flow and are common in the littoral zone of lakes during summer months, moving inshore at night. This relatively large freshwater fish is often seen at total length of 120 mm. It is a benthic species that reach 4-5 years of age, maturing at 1 year and with a generation time of 2 years. Lake populations spawn in spring and summer and river populations spawn in late winter, with adhesive eggs being deposited onto hard surfaces. Several hundred to a few thousand eggs are laid during spawning (which occurs annually) and the territorial male guards the nest site (McDowall 2000, Rowe at al. 2001, NIWA 2013).
threats: Habitats are likely to be impacted by water abstraction, agricultural development and land use changes (Ministry for the Environment 2007) and this species is also a major prey item of introduced salmoniids, particularly Brown Trout (Salmo trutta). G. cotidanus exhibits tolerance to highly eutrophic conditions and as it is present and abundant in a number of large water bodies and a variety of habitats, it is not considered to be significantly threatened by these processes.
population: This species is widespread and abundant throughout its range (NIWA 2013). No specific trend data is available however, and the population is thought be experiencing at least localized declines, as indicated by 25% declines of in presence / absence records in the national New Zealand Freshwater Fish Database over the past 12 years (NZFFD 2011). However, this data excludes lake populations and inferences about declines across the whole population cannot be made.
range: The Common Bully (Gobiomorphus cotidanus) is endemic to New Zealand where it is widely distributed throughout the main North and South Islands, Stewart Island and near offshore islands such as Great Barrier Island (McDowall 2000).
conservationActions: There are no specific conservations actions for this species and it is considered 'Not Threatened' nationally, according to the New Zealand Department of Conservation's threat classification system (Goodman et al. 2014). Monitoring of populations would be valuable to identify whether the entire population is truly declining and if so what the causes of decline are attributed to.

rationale: Retropinna retropinna is endemic to New Zealand and is the one of the most widespread native freshwater fishes in the country. It is a facultatively diadromous species that usually spends most of its life at sea, with mature adults returning to freshwater to breed, however it can also readily form landlocked populations. In some areas (for example, the Waikato River), this species migrates into freshwater as juveniles. R. retropinna is a small, pelagic, shoaling species that swims in deeper waters during the day and near the surface at night. It inhabits both flowing and still water habitats and can penetrate far inland in river systems that are not too steep. This species lives up to 4 years of age, maturing at 1 year with an average generation time of 1.5 years. Spawning takes place annually in shallow sandy margins of lakes and sandy river banks; however lake and riverine populations spawn at different times of the year. Several hundred eggs are laid during spawning. This species is considered as 'Not Threatened' in national listings. Potential threats come from the predation of introduced salmoniids (particularly Rainbow trout (Oncorhynchus mykiss) and brown trout (Salmo trutta)), for which it is the main prey in most lakes in the North Island. Other potential threats include capture of juveniles in whitebait fisheries and habitat loss and degradation caused by water abstraction, agricultural development and land use changes. It is considered that the potential effects of these are localized and therefore minimal on the overall population. Therefore, considering this species is widespread and abundant throughout its range, it has been assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: Retropinna retropinna is a facultatively diadromous fish that usually spends most of its life at sea, with mature adults returning to freshwater to breed. This species can also readily form landlocked populations, although most of these are thought to have been established by humans between 1905 and 1949 (NIWA 2013, McDowall 2010, Ward et al. 2005). In some cases (for example, the Waikato River), this species is known to migrate into freshwater as juveniles (Franklin pers. comm. 2014). R. retropinna is a small pelagic, shoaling species (typically reaching a total length of 70 mm, but specimens can attain sizes of up to 100 mm or greater), that swims in deeper waters during the day and near the water surface at night (Rowe at al. 2004). This species inhabits both flowing and still water habitats. They are not a climbing species, but are strong swimmers and will penetrate far inland in river systems that are not too steep (NIWA 2013). This species lives up to 4 years of age, maturing at 1 year with an average generation time of 1.5 years. Spawning takes place in shallow sandy margins of lakes and sandy river banks. Spawning takes place annually, however lake and riverine populations spawn at different times of the year. Several hundred eggs are laid during spawning (Ward et al. 2005).
threats: Retropinna retropinna is the main prey species of introduced salmoniids (particularly Rainbow trout (Oncorhynchus mykiss) and brown trout (Salmo trutta)) in most lakes in the North Island. In some rivers (for example, the Waikato River), juveniles are captured by whitebait fishers as they migrate upstream and mix with galaxiids. Habitats are likely to be impacted by water abstraction, agricultural development and land use changes resulting in the siltation of lowland spawning habitats in large rivers (NIWA 2013).
population: The population of this species is likely to have undergone historical declines since the arrival of European settlers in the early 1900s (from which it did not recover), however records indicate the population appears to have stabilized (NZFFD 2011). This species is listed nationally as 'Not Threatened' according to New Zealand's Department of Conservation threat classification system (Goodman et al. 2014).
range: Retropinna retropinna is endemic to New Zealand where it is occurs throughout the North and South Islands, Chatham and Stewart Islands (McDowall 1990). This is one of the most widespread native freshwater fishes in New Zealand (Ward et al. 2005).
useTrade: This species is a minor component of the whitebait fishery when caught as bycatch.
conservationActions: There are no specific conservation actions or recommendations in place for this species.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of the large extent of occurrence, large number of subpopulations, large population size, apparently stable trend, and lack of major threats.
habitat: This fish inhabits pools, backwaters, and main channels of clear to turbid waters of creeks, small to large rivers, and lakes (Lee et al. 1980, Page and Burr 2011). It spawns over sand and mud bottoms in quiet waters of streams or overflow areas in bends of rivers or bays of lakes (Scott and Crossman 1973).
threats: No major threats are known.
population:
This species is represented by a large number of occurrences (subpopulations).

Total adult population size is unknown but is very large.

Trend over the past 10 years or three generations is uncertain but likely relatively stable.
range: Range includes the Great Lakes-St. Lawrence River, Hudson Bay, and Mississippi River basins from Quebec to Alberta and south to Louisiana, west to Wyoming; Atlantic Slope drainages from the Delaware River, New York, to the Savannah River, Georgia (absent from several drainages); Gulf Slope drainages from the Apalachicola River, Florida and Georgia, to the Pearl River, Louisiana (Page and Burr 2011).
useTrade: Some are taken in commercial fisheries.
conservationActions: Currently, this species is of relatively low conservation concern and  does not require significant additional protection or major management,  monitoring, or research actions.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of the large extent of occurrence, large number of subpopulations, large population size, apparently stable trend, and lack of major threats.
habitat: White suckers occur in a wide variety of lake and stream habitats. Some migrate dozens of kilometers between nonspawning habitats (lakes or streams) and spawning areas in stream or lake tributaries. Spawning occurs usually in swift water or rapids, often in small, clear, cool creeks and small to medium rivers in water less than 30 cm deep. Sometimes spawning occurs on lake shoals, beaches, or river mouths (areas with wave action). Eggs sink and usually stick to and become lodged in gravel.
threats: No major threats are known.
population:
This species is represented by a very large number of occurrences (subpopulations).

Total adult population size is unknown but presumably exceeds 1,000,000.

Trend over the past 10 years or three generations is uncertain but likely relatively stable.
range: Large range includes Atlantic, Arctic, Great Lakes, and Mississippi River basins from Labrador to the Mackenzie River, south to the Tennessee River drainage, northern Alabama, and the Arkansas River drainage, New Mexico; south on the Atlantic Slope to the extreme upper Savannah River drainage, Georgia; South Carolina; upper Rio Grande drainage, New Mexico; Skeena and Fraser river drainages (Pacific Slope), British Columbia; introduced in the Colorado River drainage, Wyoming, Colorado, New Mexico, and Utah (Page and Burr 2011).
useTrade: This species has minor value in commercial fisheries and as a gamefish and baitfish.
conservationActions: Currently, this species is of relatively low conservation concern and  does not require significant additional protection or major management,  monitoring, or research actions.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of the large range extent, large population size, absence of significant declines, and lack of major threats.
habitat: Habitat includes pools and brushy margins in creeks and small to medium rivers (Page and Burr 2011). This bass prefers small, cool, weedy lakes or littoral regions of larger lakes, and streams with typically rocky, always silt-free substrates, permanent flow, low turbidity, and extensive cover (Lee et al. 1980). Spawning occurs in shallow water in shallow depressions made by males in areas as diverse as swamps and gravel shoals; nests may be close together (Scott and Crossman 1973).
threats: No major threats are known.
population:
This species is represented by a very large number of occurrences (subpopulations).

Total adult population size is unknown but likely exceeds 1,000,000. This bass is common in much of its range.

Trend over the past 10 years or three generations is uncertain but probably relatively stable.
range: Native range encompasses St. Lawrence-Great Lakes, Hudson Bay (Red River), and Mississippi River basins, including most of the northeastern United States and adjacent southern Canada; south to Missouri, northern Alabama, and northern Georgia, west to Saskatchewan and the eastern Dakotas. Introduced in many places on Atlantic slope south to Roanoke River, Virginia, and west of native range in Missouri, Arkansas, northeastern Oklahoma, southeastern Kansas, and some western states (Lee et al. 1980, Page and Burr 2011).
useTrade: This species is of minor value in commercial fisheries and as a gamefish.
conservationActions: Currently, this species is of relatively low conservation concern and  does not require significant additional protection or major management,  monitoring, or research actions.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of the large extent of occurrence, large number of subpopulations, large population size, apparently stable trend, and lack of major threats.
habitat: This species occurs in varied habitats; often it is in medium-sized to large creeks and small to medium rivers with gravel- or rubble-strewn riffles; it also occurs in silt-free, shallow bedrock pools with steady current, and it inhabits some relatively quiet lake shores (Lee et al. 1980, Page 1983, Page and Burr 2011). Eggs are attached to boulders or bedrock, often among filamentous algae (Page 1983).
threats: No major threats are known.
population:
This species is represented by a large number of occurrences (subpopulations).

Total adult population size is unknown but very large. This species is usually common to abundant; on the Atlantic slope, it is common only in the Potomac River (Page and Burr 2011).

Trend over the past 10 years or three generations is uncertain but likely relatively stable. In Canada (a small part of the overall range), restricted to and locally abundant in three river systems and apparently declining, perhaps due to habitat degradation (Dalton 1991).
range: Range includes the Great Lakes and Mississippi River basins from eastern Kansas and Oklahoma east to New York and western Maryland, and from southwestern Ontario south to Arkansas, Alabama, and Georgia (excluding the range of former subspecies gutselli, now regarded as a distinct species; Nelson et al. 2004); also the Atlantic slope in Mohawk, Susquehanna, and Potomac drainages, New York to Virginia; a range hiatus exists in the Former Mississippi Embayment and lowlands of Illinois and southwestern Indiana (Page and Burr 2011).
conservationActions: Currently, this species is of relatively low conservation concern and does not require significant additional protection or major management, monitoring, or research action.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of the large extent of occurrence, large number of subpopulations, large population size, apparently stable trend, and lack of major threats.
habitat: Habitat includes gravel and rubble riffles of creeks and small to medium rivers (Page and Burr 2011). Adults occur in fast and deep riffles, young in quiet shallow riffles and small pools. Eggs are laid in gravel in riffles.
threats: No major threats are known.
population:
This species is represented by a large number of occurrences (subpopulations).

Total adult population size is unknown but quite large (likely greater than 100,000). This darter is regarded as abundant (Page and Burr 2011).

Trend over the past 10 years or three generations is uncertain but likely relatively stable.
range: Range includes the Great Lakes and Mississippi River basins from Minnesota to southern Ontario and New York, south to northern Arkansas, northern Alabama, and northern Georgia; disjunct populations occur along the lower Mississippi River in eastern Louisiana and southwestern Mississippi and in the upper Potomac River drainage (Atlantic Slope), West Virginia; abundant (Page and Burr 2011).
conservationActions: Currently, this species is of relatively low conservation concern and  does not require significant additional protection or major management,  monitoring, or research action.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of the large extent of occurrence, large number of subpopulations, large population size, apparently stable trend, and lack of major threats.
habitat: Habitat includes riffles with gravel or rubble substrate in streams of 1st through 8th order (creeks and small to medium rivers); in large streams, this darter occurs in shallow areas away from main current; occasionally it occurs in lakes; it occupies deeper water in winter (Lee et al. 1980, Page and Burr 2011). Eggs are laid in flat clusters on the undersides of stones in male territories in slow to moderate current in shallow water.
threats: No major threats are known.
population:
This species is represented by a large number of occurrences (subpopulations).

Total adult population size is unknown but very large. This species is abundant in much of its range.

Trend over the past 10 years or three generations is uncertain but likely relatively stable.
range:
Range includes the Atlantic, Great Lakes, and Mississippi River basins from southern Quebec to Minnesota, and south to northeastern Oklahoma, northern Alabama, and the Peedee River system of South Carolina (Page and Burr 2011).

Subspecies brevispina: Catawba, Broad, and Peedee river drainages, North Carolina and South Carolina. Subspecies humerale: Atlantic drainages from lower Susquehanna River to the Cape Fear River. Undescribed subspecies: upper Tennessee River drainage (upstream of the Little Tennessee River), New River, and headwaters of Shavers Fork Cheat River (Monongahela River system). Subspecies flabellare: remainder of range.
conservationActions: Currently, this species is of relatively low conservation concern and  does not require significant additional protection or major management,  monitoring, or research action.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of the large extent of occurrence, large number of subpopulations, large population size, apparently stable trend, and lack of major threats.
habitat: This darter is most often found over sand or silt in quiet or sluggish areas of headwaters, creeks, and small to medium rivers (Leidy 1992, Page and Burr 1991), less often over gravel or in weedy areas of lakes or sandy lake shallows (Page 1983); sometimes in pools over bedrock (Kuehne and Barbour 1983). In Colorado, it occurs most often in shallow, slow-velocity water over cobble-sand substrate (Propst and Carlson 1989). Eggs are laid on the underside of a stone or other object.
threats: No major threats are known.
population:
This species is represented by a large number of occurrences (subpopulations).

Population size is very large. This species is common to abundant over a large area.

Trend over the past 10 years or three generations is uncertain but likely relatively stable.
range: Range includes the St. Lawrence-Great Lakes, Hudson Bay, and Mississippi River basins, from Hudson Bay to southern Mississippi and from Quebec and Virginia to Saskatchewan and Colorado; Atlantic Slope in James, Roanoke, Tar, and Neuse river drainages, Virginia and North Carolina; Gulf Slope in Mobile Bay drainage, Alabama and Mississippi; introduced in Colorado River drainage, Colorado (Page and Burr 2011).
conservationActions: Currently, this species is of relatively low conservation concern and  does not require significant additional protection or major management,  monitoring, or research action.

rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern in view of the large range extent, very large population size, and lack of significant decline.
habitat: This catfish inhabits sluggish lower reaches of coastal streams, sloughs, warmwater lakes, reservoirs, farm ponds, and tidal freshwater estuaries; it requires water above 20 °C in summer. Spawning occurs over saucer-shaped nests cleared on the bottom by males and females.
threats: No major threats are known.
population:
This species is represented by a very large number of occurrences (subpopulations).

Total adult population size probably exceeds 1,000,000.
