Independent surveys conducted by the U.S. and British Columbia have reported a significant decrease in sardine biomass (DFO 2011) and spawning stock biomass since 2006 (Hill et al. 2017). Spawning stock biomass has reached historically low levels in recent years (2014 - 2017: Hill et al. 2017). Total coast wide biomass in has declined by ~57% and ~ 79% between 2006 and 2010 in U.S. and Canadian waters, respectively (DFO 2011). The observed decrease in biomass coincided with unusual ocean conditions which may have affected overall abundance and distribution (DFO 2011), similar to other global subpopulations of this species. Recruitment in U.S. waters has also declined since 2005 - 2006 with the exception of a brief period of modest recruitment in 2009 - 2010; a small increase in recruitment was observed in 2016 but the estimate is highly variable and based off limited data (Hill et al. 2017). The 2001 - 2015 year classes have been among the weakest observed in recent history (Hill et al. 2017). Exploitation rates of this species in U.S. waters have averaged about 11 % since 2005 with peak of 13% in 2013; both the U.S. and total exploitation rates of this species in northern U.S. were less than 1%  in 2016 (Hill et al. 2017).

Southeast Pacific - This subpopulation (sometimes referred to as S. sagax sensu stricu or S. sagax sagax) is further subdivided into three units: northern (southern Ecuador to central Peru), central (southern Peru to northern Chile), and southern (off Chile: Schartzlose et al. 1999). In this region, this species is a dominant small pelagic resource along with the engraulid, Engraulis ringens (Passuni et al. 2018) where it is known to undergo periods of high and low abundance, similar to other global subpopulations. Landings reported to the FAO (1950 - 2014) from the southeast Pacific are presumably referring to this subpopulation and are driven by landings from Peru and Chile with an average of 1.1 million tonnes (FAO 2016). The trend in reported landings tracks very closely with the global trends in landings of this species and is represented by a sharp increase between 1970 and the early 1980s followed by a peak in 1985 (~6.5 million tonnes) and a sharp decline until 2014, the most recent year available in the time series (936 tonnes: FAO 2016).

Northwestern Pacific - This subpopulation (sometimes referred to as S. melanostictus or S. sagax melanostictus) is further subdivided into two units: one which occupies the Sea of Japan and East China Sea, and another which occurs along the Pacific coast (Ohshimo et al. 2009, Izzo et al. 2017). In this region, this species is important to fisheries and has experienced wide fluctuations similar to other global subpopulations (Parrish et al. 1989). Declines in landings were reported in the 1940s and the fishery was greatly reduced in the northern portion of its range (e.g., Honshu and Hokkaido) and was primarily restricted to the western Sea of Japan and East China Sea (Parrish et al. 1989). The contraction of spawning grounds was also observed during this time (Parrish et al. 1989). The subpopulation reportedly recovered in the 1970's and expanded its spawning habitat to encompass grounds around southern Kyushu (Parrish et al. 1989), specifically including Tanegashima Island, Osumi Islands (H. Hata pers. comm. 2018). The population in the NW Pacific has shown a continuous decline from about 1987 - 2003 (Nishida et al. 2005, Nishida et al. 2007). Biomass decreased from ~14 - 19 million tons in the 1980s to less than 1 million tons in the late 1990s; biomass remains at very low levels in the most recent years available (2005: Nishida et al. 2007). Additionally, egg abundance has declined by at least an order of magnitude from the 1980s to the early 2000s; juvenile abundance has also declined since the mid-1990s (Nishida et al. 2005, Nishida et al. 2007).

Southeastern Indian and southwestern Pacific - This subpopulation (sometimes referred to as S. neopilchardus or S. sagax neopilchardus) is further subdivided into at least four units with some degree of overlap: southwestern coast (off Western Australia), Great Australian Bight and Spencer Gulf, Bass Strait and Port Phillip Bay (off Victoria and Tasmania), and eastern Australia; additional evidence exists for the subdivision of units off Western Australia and the east coast (Izzo et al. 2017). This species is important to fisheries off Australian and New Zealand waters. Catches have increased since the beginning of the available time series (1975) with some fluctuation (Ward et al. 2014a, Izzo et al. 2017). Catches peaked off Western Australia in the 1990s (Izzo et al. 2017) but have remained at low levels over the last two decades following two mass mortality events which impacted the entire population in the mid - late 1990's (Ward et al. 2001, Whittington et al. 2008). A recent stock assessment off South Australia was conducted and indicated that catch and effort has increased between the years 1990 – 2016 after the establishment of a large fishery in 1991 (Ward et al. 2017); it is possible that the increase in catch is also associated with high abundance years in this region. For example, the Total Allowable Commercial Catch (TACC) has increased over the last decade from 30,000 t in 2007 - 2009, to 42,750 t in 2017; total annual catches in South Australian waters have also increased (~30,000 t in 2007 to ~38,000 t in 2016: Ward et al. 2017). Significant catches in Australia have been taken from New South Wales, Victoria and in Commonwealth waters (Ward et al. 2014b), though a large majority of catch in this region is taken from South Australia (specifically Spencer Gulf), which represents only a small portion of this species total range (Izzo et al. 2017); there is concern regarding the potential local depletion in the Spencer Gulf (Izzo et al. 2017). The fishery in South Australia (Spencer Gulf) was established in 1991 and is currently the largest fishery by volume in the country (Total Allowable Catch in 2016 was 38,000 t: Izzo et al. 2017). Effort has been relatively stable since 2007, ranging from ~760 to 1100 net-sets per year (Ward et al. 2017). Mean annual CPUE have risen from ~30 t/set-net in 2007 to over 40 t/set-net in 2015 and 2016 (Ward et al. 2017). The estimated spawning stock biomass for 2017 was estimated to be between 236,00 t - 305,000 t and is the largest obtained for the southern stock of sardine in Australian waters; the southern stock is classified as sustainable as the spawning biomass for 2017 exceeds the target reference point of 150,000 t in the harvest strategy for the South Australian Sardine Fishery (SASF: Ward et al. 2017).

Southeastern Atlantic and southwestern Indian - This subpopulation (sometimes referred to as S. ocellatus or S. sagax ocellatus) is further subdivided into at least two units: northern (Namibia) and southern (South Africa); additionally, the southern unit is broken down further into three subunits: east of Agulhas Bank, west of Agulhas Bank, and off KwaZulu-Natal (Miller et al. 2006, Izzo et al. 2017, Okomadu 2017). Limited information is available related to this subpopulation, though it is commercially important and reported to follow similar boom-bust patterns of the other four global subpopulations. This species supports a major fishery in African waters and has largely experienced major fluctuations in catches (Okumadu 2017). Off Namibia, the biomass of this unit crashed in the late 1960's; a slight recovery was observed in the 1990's but various stresses (e.g., heavy fishing pressure and abnormal environmental conditions such as hypoxia and the Benguela El Niño) caused a further decline in biomass and catches (Okumadu 2017). Presently, low sardine biomass can only allow limited fishing activity (Okumadu 2017). Within South Africa, the small pelagic fishery which targets this unit is the largest commercial fishery by volume and the second largest in net value (Okumadu 2017). The South African Sardine purse seine fishery has been concentrated along the western coast since the 1940's (Okumadu 2017). This species has undergone wide fluctuations in abundance since the beginning of industrial-scale fishing (Okumadu 2017). Similar to Namibia, high sardine catches taken in South Africa in the early 1960s were followed by drastic declines (Okumadu 2017); a slow recovery followed after management measures were put in place in the mid - 1980s (Okumadu 2017). A slight increase in biomass and catches between 2001 and 2005 (~ 4 million tonnes) resulted from good recruitment; however poor recruitment in 2004 has led to another substantial decrease in biomass in recent years (~ 250,000 tonnes in 2007 - 2008: Okumadu 2017) and has remained at a low biomass since about 2006 (DAFF 2016). In 2015, the Total Allowable Catch for this species was set below 90,000 t for the first time since 1997 which represents its depleted state in South African waters (DAFF 2016).
range: Sardinops sagax exhibits an antitropical distribution with five geographically isolated subpopulations that were given taxonomic names at some time in their history. Based on Whitehead (1985) and Parrish et al. (1989), the distributions of these five subpopulations are as follows. In the eastern Pacific, this species occurs from southeastern Alaska, south to Baja California, including the Gulf of California (sometimes referred to as S. caeruleus or S. sagax caeruleus), and from Peru to Chile including the Galapagos Islands (referred to as S. sagax sensu strictu or S. sagax sagax). In the northwestern Pacific, it occurs from Peter the Great Bay, Russia, south to at least Taiwan; H. Hata (pers. comm. 2018) reports it to be widely distributed throughout Japan from Hokkaido to Kyushu, but does not occur off the Ryukyu Islands (sometimes referred to as S. melanostictus or S. sagax melanostictus). In the southeastern Indian and southwestern Pacific, this species occurs from Shark Bay, Western Australia to the Great Barrier Reef, Queensland and New Zealand (referred to as S. neopilchardus or S. sagax neopilchardus). In the southeastern Atlantic and southwestern Indian, this species occurs from Baia dos Tigres, Angola to Durban, South Africa  (referred to as S. ocellatus or S. sagax ocellatus); more recent records report this species from Madagascar (Fricke et al. 2018) and the Macarenes (Fricke 1999). This species occurs in coastal waters to a depth of about 200 m (Munroe 2016).
useTrade:
In general, this species is one of the most important commercial fishes throughout a large portion of its range. It is caught with purse seine, trawls, gill nets and beach seines. Pilchards are marketed fresh, frozen or canned and used for fish meal and fish oil (Munroe 2016). Historically, the five subpopulations contributed about one-quarter of all clupeoid fishes caught making this the most productive out of all clupeoid genera (more than 8 million tonnes in 1983: Whitehead 1985).

Subpopulation-specific information

The northeastern Pacific subpopulation (sometimes referred to as S. caeruleus or S. sagax caeruleus) is fished by Canada, the United States and Mexico (Demer and Zwolinski 2017). Landings declined and a fishing moratorium was put in place in the late 1960s (Whitehead 1985) which was reopened in the 1980s. More recently, catches decreased by approximately 95% (1.8 million mt – 86,000 mt) off the U.S. coast between the years 2006 – 2017 warranting current fishery closures in this region (Hill et al. 2017).

The southeastern Pacific subpopulation (sometimes referred to as S. sagax sensu stricu or S. sagax sagax) undergoes large southward geographical range shifts during El Niño years; Ecuadorian and Peruvian fisheries can experience drastic declines as this species migrates out of available fishing zones (Parrish et al. 1989). It is not uncommon for total catch to exceed 1 – 2 million tons annually (Whitehead 1985). A majority of catch (~90%) is utilized for fishmeal for fish oil, ~ 4% is canned and the remaining quantity is marketed fresh or frozen (Whitehead 1985).

The northwestern Pacific subpopulation (sometimes referred to as S. melanostictus or S. sagax melanostictus) is one of the most commercially important fishes in Japan with record catches exceeding 4 million tons (Whitehead 1985). Observed catches declined sharply in the 1940s; however catches in this geographical region, as in others, generally show notable fluctuations (Whitehead 1985, Parrish et al. 1989).

Compared to other subpopulations, no globally significant fishery has existed for the southeastern Indian and southwestern Pacific subpopulation (sometimes referred to as S. neopilchardus or S. sagax neopilchardus) off Australia and New Zealand (Whitehead 1985, Parrish et al. 1989). However, based on a recent stock assessment off southern Australia, catch and effort for this species has increased between the years 1990 – 2016 (Ward et al. 2017) to be regionally important. It is commonly used as fishing bait and fodder for aquaculture, and is taken with purse seine nets (Whitehead 1985, D. Gaughan pers. obs. 2001).

The southeastern Atlantic and southwestern Indian subpopulation (sometimes referred to as S. ocellatus or S. sagax ocellatus) is taken commercially by Namibia and South Africa off virtually all western and southern coasts (Whitehead 1985). It is used for bait, aquaculture feed, fishmeal and human consumption (D. Gaughan pers. obs. 2001).
conservationActions: No known species-specific conservation measures are currently in place globally, though its total distribution overlaps with existing marine protected areas (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2018). Regional fishery management initiatives (i.e., yearly monitoring, stock assessments, quotas, limited entry fisheries and seasonal closures) are in place and implemented to a varying degree (Barange et al. 2009) throughout most of it range, especially in Australia (Ward et al. 2017) and the United States (Hill et al. 2017, Pacific Fishery Management Council 2018). Off California, fishing moratoriums have been put in place for this species during the 1960s - 1980s (Whitehead 1985), and more recently in 2015 - 2017 (Hill et al. 2017, Pacific Fishery Management Council 2018).

rationale:
Anguilla australis is a catadromous, semelparous species with multiple life stages, and is assumed to be panmictic. These life history traits, coupled with the limited information available to infer abundance trends, pose particular challenges in applying the IUCN Red List Categories and Criteria (Jacoby et al. 2015). Ideally, the IUCN Red List criteria would be applied to mature eels at their spawning grounds, and in the absence of such data, to silver eels starting their spawning migration, as these represent the maximum estimate of spawning stock biomass, but such data sets are rarely available. Analysis conducted on fisheries and monitoring data for glass eels, yellow eels and silver eels were reviewed, although the relationships between recruitment, yellow eel populations, silver eel escapement, and spawner stock biomass are poorly understood. As such, the IUCN Red List criteria must be applied to an amalgamation of multiple life stages, which provides the current best estimate of the population status.

A. australis is found in Australia, Tasmania, New Zealand, and surrounding islands (Ege 1939, Watanabe et al. 2010). Current fisheries-dependent data is available for both Australia and New Zealand. In Australia, A. australis is most commonly found in Victoria and Tasmania, where it constitutes the majority of fisheries catch at yellow eel and silver eel life stages (Inland Fisheries Service Tasmania 2009, VFA 2017). In Victoria, catch was described as having increased from 1978 to 1993, after which declines were observed in western regions between the late 1990s and early 2000s, attributed to “Millennium Drought” reducing harvestable waters (McKinnon 2002, VFA 2017). Eel fisheries in Victoria and Queensland are highly restricted and are confined to private and a small number of public impoundments stocked with wild-caught juvenile eels solely for grow-out purposes (Department of Fisheries, Agriculture and Forestry 2012, VFA 2017). This fishery data for adult eels is therefore not representative of wild eels and cannot be used to infer trends for the purpose of a conservation assessment. Also, with no metric of effort, there is increased uncertainty relating to abundance trends inferred from the reported data. In Tasmania, fishing effort data is collected, although it has not yet been reported (Inland Fisheries Service Tasmania 2009). In New Zealand, reported catch is primarily of yellow eels, as there is no targeted silver eel fishery, with exception of silver male A. australis from Te Waihora, and catch of glass eels is mostly prohibited. The North Island Eel Statistical Areas (ESAs) with available data showed either declines or no trend from when data gathering began in 1990 up to 2002, after which increasing trends in CPUE were observed (Beentjes and McKenzie 2017). In the South Island, ESAs with available data showed initial declines in the series prior to the introduction of the Quota Management System (QMS) in 2000, after which CPUE showed an increasing trend (Beentjes and Dunn 2013).

Fishery-independent data is also available for this species. Recruitment of glass eels to the Waikato River in the North Island of New Zealand appears to have declined within the last 30 years or 1.5 generation lengths (Jellyman et al. 2009). Sampling in the 2004-05 season found CPUE to have decreased by ~66% since sampling in the 1970s. However, a lack of continuous monitoring, with the most recent sampling only occurring over two years, combined with interannual variability in recruitment, makes drawing conclusions from this data difficult. Regular sampling of glass eels at sites across New Zealand from 1995–2006, showed evidence of increases of A. australis (Jellyman 2012). A. australis elver recruitment data from 1995–2015 in New Zealand has been highly variable, and in some areas shown an increase (Martin and Bowman 2016). The relationship between life-stages is poorly understood, but it is generally agreed that low recruitment will ultimately translate, though not linearly, to reduced future escapement. A study of size distribution of eels also found A. australis to show a healthy distribution, with larger proportions of small eels being present, compared to larger eels (Jellyman 2012). Records from 1977–2015 collected from the New Zealand Freshwater Fish Database (NZFFD) (in Crow et al. 2016) found an increase in the occurrence of A. australis over this period, although records were mostly from electrofishing, which may over-represent life stages in stream habitats accessible to this method (Haro et al. 2015, Crow et al. 2016).

There are a variety of documented threats to A. australis, and the life history characteristics of anguillids make them inherently more susceptible to these. In New Zealand, drainage between 1840s to 1970s has caused a reduction of wetland habitat by 85%, and as A. australis shows preference for lower reaches, estuaries and coastal areas, this has resulted in widespread habitat loss for this species (Taylor and Smith 1997, Beentjes et al. 2005, PCE 2013; Jellyman 2007, 2012, 2016). Also, flood pumping stations control water levels in lowlands where A. australis is commonly found, which can cause significant mortality to eels when sucked into pump intakes (Vaipuhi Consulting 2017, Williams et al. 2017). Across this species’ range, poor water management, including excessive surface and groundwater use, river channelisation, land clearance, and nutrient run-off, have been, and in some cases, will continue to be, detrimental to this species (Gehrke et al. 1999, PCE 2013, Jellyman 2016). Recurring drought in Victoria has resulted in a significant number of eel deaths – mainly A. australis – from both stock enhanced culture waters and of wild-caught stock. In some lakes, eels have been totally eradicated (Leahy et al. 2007a,b). Rainfall is also predicted to be reduced by 19–25% by 2090 (CSIRO and Bureau of Meteorology 2016), and so this threat is likely to continue, if not worsen.

Based on available information across this species’ range, A. australis has been listed as Near Threatened. There is evidence of historical declines in recruitment - recent data suggests increasing trends in yellow eel, silver eel, and glass eel abundance but this is only over the period of around one generation length. The extent of habitat loss across this species’ range, however, is serious cause for concern. In New Zealand, there has been a significant reduction in wetland habitat, and severe drought conditions in Australia have caused shallow lakes to become hypersaline. As reduced rainfall is predicted in southeastern Australia, this may impact this species in the future. This, coupled with other ongoing threats, such as; mortality of eels at pumping stations, habitat degradation, poor water management, and the potential for increased fishery dependency on A. australis owing to reduced quota of the sympatric A. dieffenbachii, requires a precautionary assessment to be made over the period of three generation lengths. It is therefore strongly advised that monitoring for this species be conducted to better determine population status. As with all anguillids, co-ordination of the management across this species’ range will also be pivotal for conservation.

Assessment of this species was carried out during a workshop held at the Zoological Society of London from the 5th–9th November 2018.
habitat:
There are a number of phases in an eel’s life that have specific terminology; the leaf-shaped marine larval stage is referred to as leptocephalus; these become glass eels as they reach continental waters, before developing into pigmented elvers, and then the growth phase: the yellow eel. The final stage is the marine-migratory silver eel which is characterised by silvery counter-shading and large eyes.

A. australis is principally a lowland species, inhabiting low lakes, estuaries, river reaches and wetlands, closer to coastal areas (Glova et al. 1998, Sagar et al. 2005, Beentjes et al. 2006, Jellyman 2007, 2012; PCE 2013). They have been known to migrate further inland, and it is hypothesised that the extent of A. australis found upstream is more a matter of suitable available, or accessible, habitat rather than migration ability (Glova et al. 1998). In the Southern coastal region of New South Wales for example, A. australis can be found in highland montane communities, at elevations greater than 700 m (Gehrke and Harris 2000). There is some overlap between the habitat of A. australis and A. dieffenbachii (Arai et al. 2004, Sagar et al. 2005, Jellyman 2012). Habitat preferences for juveniles of both species include shallow (<0.5 m) water, although A. australis prefers slow moving water (<0.5 m/s) (Jellyman 2007, 2012). A. australis adults prefer deep water, still with slow velocity (Jellyman 2007, 2012). Substrate preferences differ between these species, with A. dieffenbachii preferring course substrate as opposed to the fine muddy substrate that is preferred by A. australis (Glova et al. 1998; Jellyman 2007, 2012; PCE 2013). A. australis is the smallest growing of the three Australasian species, with a maximum length of 1.1 m, and weighing up to 3 kg (Jellyman 2012). Somatic growth rates of silver A. australis ranges from 14.4 to 56.6 mm/year and in general is faster than the sympatric A. dieffenbachii (Arai et al. 2004). Growth rates of A. australis in New Zealand vary between the North and South Islands (Fisheries New Zealand 2018). On the South Island, it is found to take on average 12.8 years to reach the minimum legal size of 220 g, whereas on the North Island it is found to take 5.8 years (Fisheries New Zealand 2018). A. australis is a nocturnal feeder, with a diet consisting of benthic macroinvertebrates (Jellyman 1989, Sagar et al. 2005), and individuals >50–70 mm being known to be piscivorous (Ryan 1986 in Sagar et al. 2005, Jellyman 1989). There is diet overlap between A. australis and A. dieffenbachii, so the main mechanism thought to reduce intraspecific competition between the species is through different habitat preferences (Sagar et al. 2005). A. reinhardtii also shows overlap with A. australis and A. dieffenbachii in life history, although more so with A. dieffenbachii in ecology (Chisnall 2000).

A. australis is catadromous, residing in continental waters before embarking on a seaward migration to spawn (Graynoth et al. 2008, Jellyman et al. 2009). Studies using otolith microchemistry have found A. australis to exhibit behavioural plasticity in regard to life history, with an ability to adapt to various habitats and salinities (Arai et al. 2003, 2004). A. australis is shorter lived than A. dieffenbachii (Jellyman et al. 2009). Age at spawning migration varies depending on growth rates, with males ranging between 5–22 years, at a size of 40–48 cm, and females 9–41 years and 64–80 cm (Fisheries New Zealand 2018). Although, Boubée et al. (2008) stated A. australis could migrate up to 60 years of age. A review by Jellyman (2007), estimated mean age of silver A. australis females in various regions across the North and South Islands. Values varied from 15 to 40 years, with a mean age across the regions of 23.8, although more data were available for the South Island where growth is slower (Jellyman 2007). Assessment of available data on generation length highlighted that factors such as longitude and latitude, sex and habitat quality can affect this metric. Twenty years was agreed upon after analysis. Crook et al. (2014) investigated environmental cues affecting migration of A. australis by tagging 97 yellow eels, 23 of which migrated from freshwater to estuary (Darlots Creek to Fitzroy River estuary system in Victoria) with the others remaining in freshwater. Nocturnal movement was mostly detected, with migration to the estuary occurring year-round but increasing in Southern hemisphere summer months and during high flows. Seaward migration was found to occur from late summer to early autumn, and was influenced primarily by lunar phase, and more weakly correlated with water temperature. Todd (1981) also found lunar phase and increased flow to influence seaward migration in A. australis.

A. australis is assumed to be panmictic, with the genetic structure indicating derivation from a single population (Smith et al. 2001; Jellyman 2007, 2012; Fisheries New Zealand 2018). Although, it has been questioned whether there are exists two sub-populations — A. australis australis in Australia and A. australis schmidtii in New Zealand — that are reproductively isolated with separate spawning locations (Ege 1939, Watanabe et al. 2006, Shen and Tzeng 2007, Kuroki et al. 2008). Like all anguillids, A. australis is believed to be semelparous, spawning only once before death (Fisheries New Zealand 2018). The exact spawning location is currently unknown. It has been proposed to occur either to the west of New Caledonia in the Coral Sea (Pease 2004, Gomon and Bray 2018), between Fiji and Tahiti (Castle 1963, Aoyama et al. 1999, Tesch 2003 in Kuroki et al. 2008) or northeast of Samoa (Smith et al. 2001). Spawning location is generally thought to exist within the South Equatorial Current (SEC), after which leptocephali, are likely to be transported in the SEC westward flow to the East Australian Current (EAC) (Kuroki et al. 2008). The EAC transports larvae south to their recruitment areas whilst eastward flow across the Tasman Front would transport other individuals to New Zealand (Watanabe et al. 2006, Kuroki et al. 2008). It is thought that the average larval life for A. australis is six months (Fisheries New Zealand 2018). Although it has also been proposed leptocephali take 9–10 months to reach New Zealand, in late winter to early summer (Graynoth et al. 2008). In a comprehensive review of data, average larval transport duration was found to be 7–8 months (Jellyman and Briand 2016). The mean size of glass eels of A. australis when they recruit to the New Zealand coast is 59.3 mm (Arai et al. 2004). On reaching estuaries and river mouths, larvae have metamorphosed into glass eels, with subsequent upstream migration of pigmented elvers (Fisheries New Zealand 2018). Environmental variables have been shown to affect A. australis and A. dieffenbachii glass eel migrations. In the Tukituki River, Hawke Bay, New Zealand glass eels displayed a preference for water temperatures between 12–20°C for migration, with an optimum of 16.5°C (August and Hicks 2008). Temperatures lower than 12°C and above 22°C were found to suppress glass eel catches (August and Hicks 2008). In the Waikato River, North Island, New Zealand, glass eel recruitment was studied (Jellyman et al. 2009). Glass eel migrations were found to be positively correlated with spring tides, particularly at the peak of high tide (Jellyman et al. 2009). Water temperature and discharge were also shown to significantly affect glass eel catch (Jellyman et al. 2009).

Note: Within the IUCN Habitat Classification Scheme table, most listed habitats are considered important for eels. The Marine Oceanic habitats were listed as ‘Major Importance’ due to there likely being a discrete spawning area.
threats:
Anguilla australis, like all anguillid eels, is susceptible to a number of, primarily anthropogenic, threats. These threats include but are not limited to; barriers to migration, climate change, habitat degradation, invasive species, parasitism, pollution, predation and unsustainable exploitation. The significance of any single threat, or the synergy it may have with other threats is still poorly understood (Jacoby et al. 2015). It is therefore important to highlight, that management measures focusing on a single threat, in isolation of other identified pressures, are less likely to have a significant positive effect on eel numbers. All anguillids are catadromous and semelparous, migrating from continental waters to the ocean to breed, and spawning only once before death. These traits arguably increase the impact of threats, through the terminal nature of reproduction and exposing them to pressures in both freshwater and marine environments. In comparison to the sympatric A. dieffenbachii, there is less concern surrounding the status of A. australis, primarily due to its life history; faster growth, and earlier age at seaward migration (PCE 2013). As well as this, the geographic range of A. australis is much larger than that of A. dieffenbachii (PCE 2013). Currently, habitat degradation, particularly wetland loss, fragmentation, and effects of drought, are plausibly the most prominent threats to this species (Jellyman 2009).

A. australis is the target of fisheries across its geographic range in both Australia and New Zealand, where it is the primary eel landed in Victoria (2017: 84%) (VFA 2017), Tasmania (2009: ~98.5%) (Inland Fisheries Authority Tasmania 2009), and New Zealand (2015–16: 81%) (Fisheries New Zealand 2018). In Victoria, catch is of elvers for on-growing in stock enhanced culture lakes, and silver eels (“migrating adult eels”) (McKinnon 2002, VFA 2017). In Tasmania, focus is on yellow eels with some silver eels, commercial catch of glass eels is illegal except for research or stocking purposes (Inland Fisheries Authority Tasmania 2009). In New Zealand, catch of glass eels is illegal, and therefore catch reports are of yellow and silver eels only, although minimum and maximum weight limits of 220 g and 4 kg, respectively, are currently in place to prevent catch of migrating silver eels (Jellyman 2012, Fisheries New Zealand 2018). Due to this, A. australis catch is of yellow females, as male migration occurs before reaching the minimum size, potentially creating a skewed sex ratio in escaping silver eels (Fisheries New Zealand 2018), with the exception of Te Waihora where migratory males under 220 g are also harvested (Fisheries New Zealand 2018). A study by Chisnall (1994) investigated the effects of fishing pressure in the Ahirau stream, an unexploited pastoral stream in Waikato, containing both A. australis and A. dieffenbachii. In the unexploited stream, prior to the removal of marketable sized eels, the dominant biomass was large A. dieffenbachii, which were found largely within pools. A. australis mainly inhabited shallower, faster flowing areas and were found in greater numbers, although in much smaller sizes, possibly due to territorial behaviour by A. dieffenbachii excluding A. australis from pools (Chisnall 1994). After the initial removal of eels, it was found that A. australis had a greater abundance and penetrated further upstream, and very few A. dieffenbachii were caught, including few elvers, showing little recovery and possibly poor recruitment (Chisnall 1994). It was concluded that commercial fishing pressure represents more of a threat to A. dieffenbachii than to A. australis, due to their ease of capture (Chisnall 1994). A. dieffenbachii may have previously dominated eel populations within the Waikato prior to exploitation, which has seemingly reduced the density and biomass of this species (Chisnall 1994). However, in the sites where A. dieffenbachii were recruited, interspecific competition favoured A. dieffenbachii, and the density and biomass of A. australis was reduced (Chisnall 1994). This study supports the hypothesis that the extent of A. australis found upstream is more a matter of suitable, available, or accessible habitat rather than migration ability (Glova et al. 1998).

Habitat degradation poses a threat to A. australis in New Zealand. Since European settlement began in 1840, felling of trees for timber has occurred, along with burning of forests for quick conversion to pasture faming (Beentjes et al. 2005, PCE 2013, Fisheries New Zealand 2018). By the 1980s, around 70% of the native forest had been lost (PCE 2013). Topsoil run-off as a result of forest clearing resulted in large scale erosion and sedimentation of rivers, detrimental effects of which are still being seen in the present day (PCE 2013). Although the effects of this are more detrimental to A. dieffenbachii — as A. australis prefers soft bottom muddy waters — the reduction of riparian zone compromises the overall health of the river system (Beentjes et al. 2005, PCE 2013, Fisheries New Zealand 2018). Widespread habitat loss through channel straightening and wetland drainage is a serious problem for A. australis, due to their preferences for lower reaches, coastal areas and estuaries (Beentjes et al. 2005; Jellyman 2009, 2012; PCE 2013). Where wetland drainage still occurs, and where flood pumping stations control water levels, eels can be sucked into pump intakes if they are unscreened (PCE 2013, Vaipuhi Consulting 2017). Impellors spin within the pumps, resulting in 100% mortality to eels greater than 600 mm in length, mostly migrating females; for smaller eels of a size less than 600 mm, it is significantly lower, at 12% (Vaipuhi Consulting 2017, Williams et al. 2017). Impacts of flood pumps may be greater for A. australis, as they are more prevalent in low land areas. The effects of farming irrigation have also been suggested to be detrimental to eels in New Zealand. Poor water quality resulting from greater concentrations of nutrients and sediment in the water has been linked to excessive plant growth and smothering of the stream bed, reducing habitat and food for eels (PCE 2013). The use of drainage for pastoral purposes means there is a requirement for drain cleaning (Jellyman 2012, Fisheries New Zealand 2018). This is most common in low-lying lands and is therefore a threat to A. australis (Jellyman 2012). Methods include both mechanical clearing and herbicides, and personal accounts have reported that mechanical excavation leads to eels being scooped out of the water onto banks, causing direct mortality if they cannot make it back to the watercourse (Beentjes et al. 2005, Fisheries New Zealand 2018).  

In Australia, poor water management and excessive surface and ground water use has caused river flow reduction, causing consequent negative impacts to biodiversity, increased soil salinity, and contaminant accumulation (Jellyman 2016). In the Hawkesbury-Nepean River, there have been multiple disturbances since European settlement, including clearing 37% of the catchment for land use, abstraction, pollution from run-off and sewage, and mining (Gehrke et al. 1999).

In Victoria, recurrent drought conditions from 1994 to 2007, have caused declines in the production of both stock-enhanced and wild A. australis (McKinnon 2002). The wild component of this fishery is based on silver eels (“migrating adult eels”), and during drought periods, when the stock enhanced productivity is low, reliance on the wild component increases (McKinnon 2002). In September 2006, Environmental Protection Authority (EPA) testing was conducted on Lake Martin in Victoria, where it was found that salinity was 25% higher than seawater, and the maximum depth of the lake was 50 cm, as a result of drought (Leahy et al. 2007a). In another four monitored rivers between spring 2006 and autumn 2007, eel deaths were also related to high salinity and pH conditions (Leahy et al. 2007b). In Lake Modewarre, Lake Tooliorook and Lake Bolac, a pH of 9–9.5 and a rise in salinity by 20% per month was a common factor leading to eel deaths (Leahy et al. 2007b). Drought can also affect eels through increased nutrient input and accumulation resulting in algal blooms and subsequent eutrophication (McKinnon 2002). In southeastern Australia, climate change is projected to result in reduced rainfall, in the order of 19–25% by 2090 (CSIRO and Bureau of Meteorology 2016), resulting in reduced streamflow and declining area of freshwater habitat in coastal catchments. Therefore, it seems likely that such lakes will no longer be habitable for eels, resulting in marked reductions in their distribution in mainland Australia.

The development of hydropower and dams/weirs in New Zealand is also a threat to eels, impeding upstream and downstream migration, and reducing the amount of suitable available habitat (Beentjes et al. 2005, Boubée et al. 2008, Graynoth et al. 2008, Jellyman 2012). Although A. australis has been found not to travel as far inland as A. dieffenbachii, this may still pose a threat to migration (Jellyman 2012). Even with programmes such as trap and transfer, females predominantly reside further upstream, and the inability to complete seaward migration can cause skewed sex ratios during spawning (Beentjes et al. 2005). During downstream migration, mortality of larger eels in hydroelectric turbines can be up to 100%, dependent on turbine speed and type (Beentjes et al. 2005, Jellyman 2012, Fisheries New Zealand 2018). Upstream migration of glass eels can also be affected by barriers, and even with the addition of fishways to allow safe passage, the high velocity of flows out of the fishway may restrict glass eel migration (Langdon and Collins 2000). In Australia, dams also pose a threat to eels. An example is Tallowa Dam, found in the Shoalhaven River, in New South Wales. Sampling of fish species at the dam found A. australis and A. reinhardtii living immediately below (Gehrke et al. 2002). Unlike many other species, A. australis and A. reinhardtii were able to pass over the dam, by climbing the spillway wall (Gehrke et al. 2002). Despite their ability to climb the wall, the large accumulations of these two species occurring at the base of the dam highlights the effect of barriers on slowing migration, as well as associated density dependent effects; increased risk of predation, potential for over-exploitation through fishing, and increased risk of mortality as a result of disease epidemics occurring in confined habitats (Gehrke et al. 2002). Since this time, a high-level fish lift commenced operation on Tallowa Dam in 2009 to reinstate fish passage. By 2014, A. australis were only using the fishway infrequently, compared to A. reinhardtii which passed through the fishway in much larger numbers (Walsh et al. 2014). Only a single individual of A. australis was caught upstream after commissioning the fishway, compared to 185 A. reinhardtii. No A. australis were caught immediately below the dam suggesting that A. australis remains a relatively uncommon species in the Shoalhaven River system (Walsh et al. 2014).

Changes in ocean-atmospheric conditions have been implicated in the decline in recruitment seen in all temperate anguillid species (Miller et al. 2009). For some species, this involves El Niño Southern Oscillation (ENSO) events, which have potentially been affecting spawning and recruitment of A. australis and A. dieffenbachii (Miller et al. 2009). Alterations in surface layer characteristics (productivity/community structure) may also have occurred due to ocean warming, affecting both larval feeding and transport (Miller et al. 2009). In the Tukituki River, Hawke Bay, New Zealand, glass eels (both A. australis and A. dieffenbachii) migrating upstream were found to display preference for water temperatures between 12–20°C, with an optimum of 16.5°C (August and Hicks 2008). Temperatures lower than 12°C and above 22°C were found to supress glass eel catches (August and Hicks 2008). It was therefore implied that warmer waters occurring as a result of the changing climate may be detrimental to glass eel recruitment in the native range of these species (August and Hicks 2008). In the North Island Waikato River, glass eel recruitment (both A. australis and A. dieffenbachii) was also studied over a period of two years (2004–05) (Jellyman et al. 2009). Comparison of catch results from this study with previous catch data (30 years apart), found glass eel migration periods to occur earlier in the present study, by several weeks (Jellyman et al. 2009). It was also found that reduced CPUE and duration of runs in the recent sampling, indicating a reduction in recruitment may also have occurred (Jellyman et al. 2009). One possible explanation given, was that deviations were a result of climate change, as although no consistent national trend exists, fresh water temperatures in New Zealand have increased by ~1.6°C from 1989-2005 (Scarsbrook 2006 in Jellyman et al. 2009). Glass eels sampled by Jellyman et al. (2009) were caught between temperatures of 12.6°C and 13.1°C, substantially below the 16.5°C optimum suggested by August and Hicks (2008). There was also evidence that glass eels may compensate for increased temperature through earlier seasonal migration (Jellyman et al. 2009). Therefore, if they were to wait for river temperatures >12°C before beginning upstream migration, the time window would become limited (Jellyman et al. 2009). For these studies, catches in both the Tukituki and Waikato were both predominantly A. australis, 91–93% and >97%, respectively (August and Hicks 2008, Jellyman et al. 2009).
population:
In New Zealand, there is less concern over the population of A. australis than the sympatric A. dieffenbachii (Haro et al. 2015). The most recent data available from New Zealand is from the Fisheries New Zealand Fisheries Assessment Plenary, published in May 2018. This document is a summary of fisheries, biological, environmental, stock assessment, and stock status information for commercial fish species in New Zealand. The first available catch data (landings, tonnes (t)) of yellow, and to a lesser extent, silver eels, is from 1965, although up to 1989–90 this encompassed landings of both shortfin (A. australis) and longfin (A. dieffenbachii), with the latter making up ~25% of commercial eel catch (PCE 2013). Although not a legislative requirement, there are no targeted fisheries for silver eels - with the exception of silver male A. australis from Te Waihora) in New Zealand (Jellyman 2007). This is due to capture being difficult at high flow periods when most migrate, and voluntary bans among fishers to support the sustainability of the stock (Jellyman 2007). Australasian longfin (A. reinhardtii), after identification in 1996 (Jellyman et al. 1996), has been confirmed in North Island landings, although the percentage is unknown and thought to contribute very little, so is included and managed within ‘shortfin’ (A. australis) stocks. Catch data prior to 1988 was also collected by calendar year not fishing season, which straddle years. Fisheries New Zealand (2018) reports landings (t) of both ‘shortfin’ and ‘longfin’ from 1989–90 to 2015–16. In 1989–90, landings of ‘shortfin’ eels totalled 617 t, in 2015–16 this decreased to 378 t, a decline of ~39%. However, the effects of market demand, quotas, voluntary non-targeting, and fishery closures (Williams et al. 2017), mean it would not be accurate to infer population declines solely from the landings data presented within the Fisheries Assessment Plenary.

Catch Per Unit Effort (CPUE) data is available for New Zealand by Eel Statistical Area (ESA), a list of which can be found in Fisheries New Zealand (2018). For North Island ESAs — not including Wellington (ESA AM), due to lack of data — from 1990–91 to 2014–15, CPUE for ‘shortfin’ (A.australis with small proportion of A. reinhardtii) showed either declines or no trend up to 2002, after which it increased (Beentjes and McKenzie 2017). For Northland (ESA AA), CPUE did not show the declines, and exhibited a steady increase throughout the series (Beentjes and McKenzie 2017). Increased CPUE is suggested to have occurred as a result of the Total Allowable Commercial Catch (TACC) reductions in 2007–08 as well as voluntary reductions in Annual Catch Entitlement (ACE) by iwi — the political unit of the Māori representing customary and commercial interests — prior to this. Estimates of CPUE are described as being conservative following 2007 due to non-reporting of legal sized eels returned to the water, a consequence of fishers not having enough ACE to cover the catch, but also voluntarily forgoing opportunities to fulfil their ACE (Williams et al. 2017). The increased size of fyke net escape tubes — a mechanism to allow eels under the size restriction to escape — from 25 mm to 31 mm in 2013–14 to exclude eels <300 g will also have contributed to these conservative estimates (Beentjes and McKenzie 2017).

Analysis of CPUE has also been conducted for South Island ESAs from 1990–91 to 2012–13 (Beentjes and Dunn 2013). In data poor areas (Nelson (ESA AN), Marlborough, South Marlborough (ESAs AP-AQ), North and South Canterbury (ESA AR, AT), and Waitaki (ESA AU)) prior to the Quota Management System (QMS), there were indications of a declining trend between 1991–2000, most prominently in Marlborough and South Marlborough (Beentjes and Dunn 2013). For areas in which there was more data (Westland (ESA AX), Otago (ESA AV), Southland (ESA AW) and Te Waihora (AS1)), CPUE showed initial declines in Otago and Southland prior to the QMS, and in Westland this decline was followed by an increase (Beentjes and Dunn 2013). After the introduction of the QMS in 2000, there was an increase in CPUE for all ESAs, but this was most prominent in Southland and Te Waihora (Beentjes and Dunn 2013).

Records from 1977–2015 collected from the New Zealand Freshwater Fish Database (NZFFD) were analysed by Crow et al. (2016) using a generalised linear model, to estimate the probability of capture as an index of relative abundance for each year of record. Two analyses were carried out, one using probability of capture values only, and one that was weighted, through placing higher emphasis on observations for which there is greater confidence. Within all analyses, both weighted and unweighted, across the whole time series, and only using data from 1995–2015, occurrence of A. australis increased. The data within NZFFD records are collected country-wide, possibly suggesting country-wide trends, however, records were mostly from electrofishing which may over-represent life stages in stream habitats accessible to this method (Haro et al. 2015, Crow et al. 2016).

In Australia, Victoria is the main area for fishing A. australis. The Victorian Eel Fishery uses both wild caught and stock enhanced commercial catch, whereby eel production through stock enhancement involves catch of elvers and on-growing in ‘culture’ lakes under natural conditions (McKinnon 2002, VFA 2017). This method comprises 40% of the commercial catch, the rest being wild catch of silver eels (“migrating adult eels”) (McKinnon 2002). Fishery data from 1978–2016 is reported as annual catch with no metric of effort and consists of both wild caught and stock enhanced eels (yellow/silver) (VFA 2017). A. australis represents 84% of catch over the period 1978–2016, with the other 16% consisting of A. reinhardtii (VFA 2017). Catch generally increased from 1978 to 1993, after which declines observed in western regions during the late 1990s, and early 2000s were attributed to the “Millennium Drought” affecting fishery viability, particularly of ‘culture’ waters but also wild caught stocks (VFA 2017). In Tasmania, the eel fishery reports catch of yellow and silver eels, largely focussing on A. australis. Fishing effort data is collected although has “not yet been analysed and reported” (Inland Fisheries Service Tasmania 2009). Activity is closely linked to the market and so fishers will not fish if prices are too low to attain commercial benefit, and fishing effort is also affected by drought, with expected higher CPUE occurring when drought conditions concentrate eels, creating more efficient fishing (Inland Fisheries Service Tasmania 2009). The Queensland Eel Fishery combines catch of yellow and silver (>30 cm) A. australis and A. reinhardtii, although primarily A. reinhardtii (Department of Fisheries, Agriculture and Forestry 2012). CPUE for this fishery showed a steep decline from just under 160 kg/day in 2004, to around 30 kg/day in 2007. From 2007–2012, CPUE has remained constant at just over 30 kg/day. Since 2012, CPUE has increased up to ~40 kg/day in 2017, 2016 was an exception to this, with only 25 kg/day (Daf.qld.gov.au 2018). Harvest of yellow and silver eels in the Queensland Eel Fishery is from “artificial impoundments” where juvenile eels have been stocked for grow-out purposes, CPUE is therefore stated to be “not representative of wild adult eel stocks” (Department of Fisheries, Agriculture and Forestry 2012). Stock status for this fishery is described as “sustainably fished” (owing to “strict conditions related to permitted fishing areas”) (Queensland Government 2010, Department of Fisheries, Agriculture and Forestry 2012). In New South Wales, catch of eels is primarily (90%) A. reinhardtii, with reports of landings combining this with A. australis (Stewart et al. 2015). Indices of CPUE are calculated for this fishery, which remained stable from 1997–98 to 2008–09 before a slight increase from 2008–09 to 2011–12 and subsequent decline to 2013–14 (Stewart et al. 2015). Whilst some reports describe A. australis as being abundant in New South Wales coastal rivers (Beumer 1996), intensive quantitative surveys found this species to be relatively uncommon in the southern coastal region, with only a single individual caught in the northern coastal region (Harris and Gehrke 1997).

Jellyman et al. (2009) provided the first strong indication that recruitment of A. australis glass eels had declined in the Waikato River in New Zealand. When comparing sampling of Anguilla spp. (both A. australis (97%) and A. dieffenbachii (3%)) during 2004–05 to previous sampling in the 1970s, CPUE (kg / net h) had declined by ~66% over ~30 years, from 5.80 ± 1.25 in the 1970s, to 1.99 ± 0.96 in 2004–05. However, conclusions based on two years' data must be provisional, as interannual variation in recruitment can be 10-fold (Francis and Jellyman 1999, in Jellyman et al. 2009). As part of a Public Good Science Fund (PGSF) research programme on eels, the National Institute of Water and Atmospheric Research (NIWA) in New Zealand conducted regular sampling for glass eels (Jellyman 2012). The data series ran from 1995 to 2006, and analysis was conducted on glass eel catches sampled at two weekly intervals during September and October (Jellyman 2012). The analysis found A. australis glass eel density increased over the sampling period, and also was greater than that of A. dieffenbachii, (Jellyman 2012). However, the time period assessed in this paper is relatively short in comparison to generation length (20 years), and other studies (Jellyman et al. 2009) have found evidence of recruitment declines (Jellyman 2012). Since 1995, the Ministry for Primary Industries (MPI) has been monitoring recruitment through elver trap and transfer operations at hydro dams. Martin and Bowman (2016), estimated recruitment trends between 1995 and 2015, using the data collected from six locations: Wairua Falls Power Station, Karapiro Dam, Matahina Dam, Patea Dam, Waitaki Dam and Arnold Dam. Trends in catch indices are largely variable, although in Karapiro and Matahina, for both A. dieffenbachi and A. australis, catch peaked between 2007 and 2009, underwent a sharp decline in 2011–12, before again increasing in 2014–15. In the South Island, there were large gaps in data, making it difficult to discern trends. Arnold Dam showed declines from 2007–08, although increased in 2014–15. When investigating size distribution of eels, Jellyman (2012) found a healthy distribution for A. australis consisting of a larger proportion of small eels (50–99 mm, 100–149 mm) being present, compared to larger eels.

Wetland drainage has resulted in a huge loss of habitat for A. australis in New Zealand (Jellyman 2016). Since European settlement in the 1840s, to the mid-1970s, lowland wetlands have been progressively drained, resulting in a reduction from around 670,000 ha to 100,000 ha (85%) (Taylor and Smith 1997, Beentjes et al. 2005, PCE 2013; Jellyman 2007, 2012, 2016). The wetland areas that remain have been subject to other stressors, such as pollution, animal grazing and introduced plants (Taylor and Smith 1997). Droughts occurring in Victoria have also been linked to declines in both wild-caught and stock-enhanced A. australis (McKinnon 2002). Western region declines in catch from 1990–2000 were attributed to the drought conditions reducing areas of harvest, particularly in stock enhanced culture waters (VFA 2017). Although, with no metric of effort within this series, it is difficult to validate this. In 1999, in Lake Gnarpurt, western Victoria, an algal bloom resulting from drought conditions killed an estimated 100 t of eels (McKinnon 2002). In the summers of 2004–05 and 2005–06, there were records of severe cases of eel deaths in the Western District of Victoria (Leahy et al. 2007a). In 2004–05, ten waterways recorded eel deaths, although fewer than 100 eels each time. In January of 2005, there was 5000 recorded dead eels in Lake Modewarre. A repeat event occurred in January and February 2006, with 20 t — estimated to be 50,000 individuals — of dead eels recorded, and there is now said to be “doubts amongst commercial fishers whether there are any eels surviving in this lake, let alone commercially viable quantities” (Leahy et al. 2007a). In Lake Bolac, another large eel death event was recorded in January 2006 of 5000 eels, and in February 2006 more than 200 dead eels were observed on the shore of Lake Martin (Leahy et al. 2007a). A monitoring programme running from spring 2006 to autumn 2007 was conducted in four lakes (Lake Modewarre, Lake Colac, Lake Tooliorook, and Lake Bolac), of these, two large eel deaths occurred in lakes that support commercial eel fishing (Leahy et al. 2007b). From late November to early December 2006, it was estimated that in Lake Tooliorook, 75,000 eels died, and in Lake Bolac, the largest of the deaths, an estimated 95,000 eels, was recorded in March 2007 (Leahy et al. 2007b). Following these events, it was considered unlikely that any eels remained within these two lakes by the end of autumn 2007 (Leahy et al. 2007b). Eels were believed to remain in Lake Colac, thought to be the last large inland lake eel population, the retention of which was dependent on future drought conditions (Leahy et al. 2007b). Eel deaths occurring in the western lakes were mostly comprised of large females said to be in “good condition” (Leahy et al. 2007a). A. reinhardtii may also comprise some of the biomass in these events, although this species isn’t as common in Victoria as A. australis (VFA 2017). Drought has continued in Victoria, and although re-stocking took place in 2016, this was of mostly rainbow and brown trout (Tagried Kurwie pers. comm. 2019). In southeastern Australia, climate change is projected to result in reduced rainfall, in the order of 19–25% by 2090 (CSIRO and Bureau of Meteorology 2016), resulting in reduced streamflow and declining area of freshwater habitat in coastal catchments. Therefore, it seems likely that such lakes will no longer be habitable for eels, resulting in marked reductions in their distribution in mainland Australia.

Under the New Zealand Threat Classification Series, A. australis has been assessed as ‘Not Threatened’ (species with large stable populations), with qualifier ‘Inc’ for increasing (Dunn et al. 2018). The New Zealand Threat Classification Series defines population as “The total number of individuals that are resident or that breed in New Zealand” referring solely to mature individuals (Townsend et al. 2008). For a ‘Not Threatened’ taxon, there must be 20,000–100,000 or >100,000 mature individuals, and the population trend must be stable (±10%) or increasing (>10%) (Townsend et al. 2008). The qualifier ‘Inc’ refers to an ongoing or predicted increase of >10% in the total population taken over the next 10 years or 3 generations, whichever is longer (Townsend et al. 2008). The difficulty with assessing an anguillid species using this terminology, as with the IUCN classification, is that there is no direct metric for ‘mature individuals’, as eels are not considered mature until they reach breeding grounds to spawn. Therefore, it is necessary to assess them using a suitable alternative metric (for example, silver eel escapement/glass eel recruitment). Within the New Zealand Threat Classification Series assessment, there is no indication as to what metric was used or reasoning as to why that metric was decided to be an appropriate alternative.
range: Anguilla australis, is a temperate eel (Arai et al. 2004) found in New Zealand, eastern Australia, Tasmania, Norfolk Island, Lord Howe Island, New Caledonia (Ege 1939) and the Chatham islands (Watanabe et al. 2006). It is most abundant in latitudes 35–44oS, although is distributed 20–54oS (Beumer and Sloane 1990, Shiao et al. 2002). A. australis mostly inhabits lowlands, dominating lakes, estuaries, low river reaches and wetlands (Jellyman 2007, 2012; PCE 2013). Upper altitudes occur at around 250 m southwest of the North Island of New Zealand around Mt. Ruapehu, with occasional records higher (>400–500 m) (GBIF 2018). In the Southern coastal region of New South Wales, A. australis is a characteristic species of montane rivers at elevations above 700 m (Gehrke and Harris 2000). The precise spawning location for A. australis is unknown, although it is thought to occur to the west of New Caledonia in the Coral Sea (Pease 2004, Gomon and Bray 2018), it has also been proposed to lie between Fiji and Tahiti (Castle 1963, Aoyama et al. 1999, Tesch 2003 in Kuroki et al. 2008) or northeast of Samoa (Smith et al. 2001). It is assumed that this species is panmictic, utilising a single spawning ground (Smith et al. 2001; Jellyman 2007, 2012; Fisheries New Zealand, 2018), although it has been questioned whether there are two sub-populations with separate spawning areas (Watanabe et al. 2006, Shen and Tzeng 2007, Kuroki et al. 2008).
useTrade:
The various life stages, ranging from juvenile to adult, of all anguillid species are harvested and traded on a global scale for farming and consumption, with current demand predominantly driven by East Asian markets, in particular Japan and mainland China. A concerning pattern of exploitation is already apparent – when one Anguilla species or population becomes over-exploited, industry moves to the next in order to fulfil demand (Gollock et al. 2018).

According to FAO data, annual global Anguilla production has steadily increased since the 1950s, mainly due to the expansion of farming in East Asia. In 2016, eel farming accounted for 98% of total eel production (over 290,000 t), with mainland China responsible for nearly 86% (FAO 2018). Eel farming is reliant on wild-caught juvenile eels (glass eels/elvers) as “seed” as breeding in captivity is not yet commercially viable. Although the preferred species for farming in East Asia is A. japonica, which is native to the region, declines in availability and ongoing demand has led to increase in harvest and trade in juveniles of other Anguilla spp. in recent years (Shiraishi and Crook 2015, Gollock et al. 2018). Catch or export of glass eels from New Zealand is not permitted (apart from small quantities for research purposes), and where catch of juvenile eels is permitted in Australia, they may not be exported and can only be sold to aquaculture operations within Australia, of which there are currently very few. However, based on East Asian Customs data, Hong Kong reported imports of 1761 kg of live eel fry from Australia in 2014–2015 and Korea 180 kg in 2015–2016, suggesting there may be some illegal trade/demand for either A. australis or A. reinhardtii juvenile eels, despite there being no information that these species are currently used in eel farms in East Asia (Gollock et al. 2018).

Live eels and meat are traded globally for consumption and to a much smaller extent Anguilla skins and leather products are also in international trade. Global Customs trade data for live, fresh, frozen and prepared/preserved eel (non-species-specific) are available for the last 40 years.  According to FAO and UN Comtrade, global annual exports of Anguilla averaged around 20,000 t in the late 1970s, after which annual exports showed a steady increase to a maximum of over 130,000 t in 2001. Since then annual exports have been declining, to just over 80,000 t in 2008–2011, increasing again slightly to ~90,000 t in 2013–2015. The export value of these commodities has steadily increased over the past 40 years, reaching USD ~1.6 billion in 2012. Over the last decade, of the four commodity types, live and prepared/preserved eel accounted for nearly 80% of total exports by weight, and China has been the main eel exporter (52% and 71% of global exports by weight and value respectively during 2006–2015) and Japan the main importer (for 54% and 72%). As noted above, a high percentage of eel in international trade is derived from eels having been grown out in farms. Trade in A. australis on the other hand is predominantly in wild or stocked eels.

In New Zealand, eels (known in Te Reo as “tuna”) feature extensively in Māori mythology and large eels are considered spiritual guardians of waterways.  To this day, eels are important to Māori for cultural reasons. In some cases, they are considered a delicacy and are served at various functions. Prior to European settlement, Māori already had extensive knowledge of the ecology of eels and developed effective fisheries through combinations of traps, spearing, bait fishing and large weirs (McDowall 1990, 2011; Jellyman, 2012). The extent of current or past non-commercial take in New Zealand is unknown, however current allowances for customary and recreational take of shortfin eels (A. australis) as of 2018 were set at: 15.2% of TAC (74 t) in the North Island, and 19.9% of TAC (65 t) in South Island, for customary take. For recreational take, allowances were 13% of TAC (63 t) in the North island, and 2.9% of TAC (9.4 t) in the South Island (Ministry for Primary Industries 2019c).

Large scale commercial yellow and silver eel fisheries of domestic species began in New Zealand in the 1960s with the arrival of Dutch immigrants to New Zealand, who had both the knowledge of eel fisheries and the ability to make and use fyke nets (McDowall 1990). The fishery grew rapidly until annual catches of 2000 t were recorded in the early 1970s. Annual landings were relatively stable from 1983 to 2001 (~1000–1500 t), after which they dropped as eel stocks were progressively introduced into the Quota Management System (QMS), TACCs were reduced and international demand declined (Fisheries New Zealand 2018). Over the last decade, total commercial annual catch has ranged between about 450–750 t. A. australis catch has accounted for around 70–80% of this: ranging between ~370 and 520 t a year (Fisheries New Zealand 2018). In the early 1990s, there were 23 licensed eel processing factories operating in New Zealand, in 2012 there were only 4 or 5 remaining (Jellyman 2012). 

The majority of New Zealand eel catch (>70%) is exported, with the main domestic consumption being by Māori customary fishers (New Zealand Ministry for Primary Industries 2018). A. australis eels between 500 g and 1 kg are often exported live; according to industry sources, this is to ensure freshness, and to sell in markets and restaurants that specialise in providing live fish in tanks for selection by customers (New Zealand Ministry for Primary Industries 2018). According to New Zealand Customs data (which does not differentiate between eel species), New Zealand exported 3,636 t of frozen eels and 2,818 t of live eels during 2008–2017. Annual frozen eel exports ranged between 152 and 380 t during 2008–2017 except for 2010 when these exceeded 1,189 t with sudden increases in frozen eel exports to South Korea (926 t). Except in 2010, the main destinations of frozen eels were Belgium, the UK and Germany. Live eel exports reached a peak of 517 t in 2011, after which they declined gradually to 133 t in 2016. The main destinations of live eels were South Korea until 2013, mainland China (2014–2016) and Canada in 2017. Jellyman (2012) reported that there has been a substantial increase in the price that New Zealand eels are fetching on overseas markets, although details are scarce.

Freshwater eels have a long history as a food source throughout their range in eastern Australia, firstly as part of the subsistence diet of aboriginal people (for whom eels also have a strong cultural significance) and then as a commercial fishery developed by European settlers since the early 1900s (Pease 2004). Due to its more temperate distribution, A. australis dominates commercial catches in Victoria and Tasmania (McKinnon 2002, DEPI 2013). Take by recreational and indigenous fisheries is expected to be low: a Queensland state-wide recreational fishing survey undertaken in 2010 indicated that recreational take of eels was approximately 2000 adult eels per year. Australia started reporting eel farming production to FAO in 1984. After reaching peaks of 315 t in 1997 and 1998, farming production has steadily declined, and none has been reported since 2012 (FAO 2018).


In Victoria, A. australis is the most abundant and predominately fished eel species, making up approximately 80% of the total annual catch of eels in Australia (Baker 2010). The first commercial catches of eels in Victoria were recorded in 1914 and until the 1950s the commercial eel fishery was based on supplying bait to the rock lobster and long-line shark fisheries (export of A. australis to Europe commenced only in the early 1960s). Four of the life stages (glass eels, elvers, yellow eels and silver eels) are commercially utilized in Victoria, but a major component of the Victorian commercial eel fishery consists of adult eels at various stages of migration (Baker 2010). Yellow and silver eels are commercially fished for domestic and export markets and glass eels and elvers are used for stock enhancement and aquaculture (Baker 2010). Catch of glass eels has been found to have been of “limited success due to the highly variable abundance in Victoria” and currently there is no on-growing occurring in intensive aquaculture facilities in the state (VFA 2017).

In Tasmania, A. australis makes up ~98.5% of the catch (Inland Fisheries Authority Tasmania 2009). The commercial fishery in Tasmania is based on the harvest of eels larger than 300 mm in length. Fishing activity in Tasmania has been shown to be heavily influenced by eel price and market demand: eel fishers will cease or reduce fishing effort if eel prices are too low prohibited (Inland Fisheries Authority Tasmania 2009). Interest in eel culture has led to periodic aquaculture trials but has not progressed into commercial development. Other glass eel catch is carried out for research or stocking purposes at sites where barriers impede natural migration, but commercial fishing of glass eels is prohibited (Inland Fisheries Authority Tasmania 2009). 

Fishing for A. australis also occurs in Queensland and New South Wales, although is not the main focus of these fisheries. A. australis makes up around 10% of the catch in the New South Wales Estuary General Fishery (Pease 2004). Aquaculture of eels also exists in New South Wales, although production is small, and a precautionary approach is being taken with respect to glass eel harvest (Dpi.nsw.gov.au 2018b).

There is a limited domestic market for eels in Australia, and most is exported to Asia (live) and Europe (frozen) (Australian Department of the Environment and Energy 2018). According to UN Comtrade, Australia exported 2,635 t of eel commodities (all species) during 2007–2016, 91% of which were live eel exports. Live eel exports reached a peak of ~370 t in 2012, after which they gradually decreased to 96 t in 2016. Hong Kong was the dominant destination of live eels from Australia, accounting for 84% of live eel exports from the country between 2007 and 2016.
conservationActions:
There has been previous debate over the taxonomic status of A. australis, with some suggesting the possibility of two sub-species. This debate has led to questions over whether there should be separate management for each sub-species (Watanabe et al. 2006, Shen and Tzeng 2007, Leander et al. 2012). Jellyman (2007), stated that they are found to show genetic homogeneity at the glass eel stage, and should therefore be managed cooperatively by Australia and New Zealand as if it were a single population. Currently, management of A. australis is independent across Australian states and New Zealand.

In Australia, fisheries target both the shortfin eel (Anguilla australis) and the Australian longfin eel (Anguilla reinhardtii). The Victorian Eel Fishery is managed in accordance with the Fisheries Act 1995 and Fisheries Regulations 2009 (VFA 2018). The latest Victorian Eel Fishery Management Plan was published in 2017, which sets out management arrangements, objectives, strategies and actions of the fishery for the next five years (VFA 2017). Victoria does not operate closed seasons for the commercial harvest of eels (VFA 2017). The Tasmanian Eel Fishery is managed in accordance with the Inland Fisheries Act 1995 and Inland Fisheries Regulations 1996 (Australian Government 2004). A management plan does not exist for this fishery, although the latest assessment was published in 2016 (Australian Government 2016). The fishery is managed through gear restrictions, geographically defined licencing, closed catchments and significant protection of glass eels/elvers and migrating silver eels (Inland Fisheries Service Tasmania 2009). The Queensland Eel Fishery management regime falls under the Fisheries Act 1994, Fisheries Regulation 2008, Policy for Management Arrangements for the Commercial Harvesting and use of Juvenile Eels (The Juvenile Eel Policy), and Integrated Planning Act 1997 (for juveniles harvested for aquaculture) (Department of Fisheries, Agriculture and Forestry 2012). The Queensland fishing season runs from 1st January to 31st December, and the latest assessment of the fishery under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 was published in 2014 which includes a summary of issues and recommendations (Australian Government 2014). The eel fishery in Queensland is a closed fishery, with non-transferrable licences. For New South Wales, harvest of eels occurs as part of the Estuary General Fishery (multi-species), under the enforcement legislation: NSW Fisheries Management (Estuary General Share Management Plan) Regulation 2006, NSW Fisheries Management Act 1994, NSW Fisheries Management (General) Regulation 2010, and NSW Fisheries Management (Supporting Plan) Regulation 2006 (Australian Government 2018, Dpi.nsw.gov.au. 2018a). An assessment for this fishery under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 (EBPC act) was conducted in 2018, depicting where the fishery meets or does not meet the guidelines set out by the EPBC act (Australian Government 2018).

Fishways are used in Australia to mitigate the impact of obstructions to fish passage (Jones and O’Connor 2017). The Victorian Waterway Management Strategy (VWMS) is a framework for waterway management, covering the maintenance and improvement of water conditions (DEPI 2013, Jones and O’Connor 2017).  Policies within this framework look at improving connectivity, and therefore relate to eel passage (Jones and O’Connor 2017). New South Wales manages fish passage under the NSW Fisheries Management Act 1994, whereby all new structures must consider fish passage, and the restoration of old structures that require a method of fish passage occurs (Thorncraft and Harris 2000). Concerns over a growing urban population in Sydney, and the construction of dams in the Hawkesbury-Nepean catchment to supply water to the Sydney metropolitan area, led to the enactment of the Water Board Corporatisation Act 1994, that required the Sydney Water Corporation to protect the aquatic environment through more sustainable practises, including the installation and commissioning of a high-level fishway on Tallowa Dam (Gehrke et al. 1999). In Tasmania, fish ladders have been installed to promote fish passage. An elver ladder was built at the Trevallyn Dam in 1996, although the ladder has now been de-commissioned, and other improvements made for passage of elvers (Inland Fisheries Service Tasmania 2009). Hydro Tasmania reports it “is continuing to examine options to mitigate the impacts of dam and power generation infrastructure on spawning migrations of silver eels” (Inland Fisheries Service Tasmania 2009). West of New South Wales, on Tallowa Dam in Shoalhaven River, a high-level fish lift commenced operation in 2009 (Walsh et al. 2014). By 2014, A. australis were only using the fishway infrequently, compared to A. reinhardtii which passed through the fishway in much larger numbers (Walsh et al. 2014). Only a single individual of A. australis was caught upstream after commissioning the fishway, compared to 185 A. reinhardtii (Walsh et al. 2014).

In New Zealand, there is an annual meeting of the Eel Working Group focusing on eel fisheries management. This involves the Ministry of Fisheries fishery managers, the iwi — political unit of the Māori representing customary and commercial interests — commercial fishers, processers, the Seafood Industry Council, the Department of Conservation and research providers (Jellyman 2012). The meetings involve discussions surrounding research priorities, reviewing research outcomes and reviewing the annual report on eels (Ministry of Fisheries assessment plenary) (Jellyman 2012).

The New Zealand fishing season for all eel stocks extends from 1st October to 30th September, apart from Te Waihora/Lake Ellesmere, where since 2002 the season is 1st February to 31st January (Fisheries New Zealand 2018). A Quota Management System (QMS) was introduced to New Zealand in 1986, to control the amount of fish taken from each stock (Ministry for Primary Industries, 2019a). On 1st October 2000, the South Island eel fishery was introduced to the QMS, combining ‘shortfins’ (A. australis with some A. reinhardtii) and ‘longfins’ (A. dieffenbachii) within six stocks. The Chatham Island fishery followed, introducing the QMS on the 1st October 2003, with one stock for ‘shortfins’ and one for ‘longfins’. The North Island fishery was introduced on the 1st October 2004, with eight fish stocks, four for each ‘shortfins’ and ‘longfins’ (Fisheries New Zealand 2018). On 1st October 2017 the South Island stocks were finally separated into ‘longfins’ and ‘shortfins’, to allow species specific management (Fisheries New Zealand 2018).

The QMS involves establishing Total Allowable Catch (TAC) (In 2018: 327.59 t South Island, 486 t North Island) for each fish stock, which is split into: Total Allowable Commercial Catch (TACC) (In 2018: 77% of TAC (252.1 t) South Island, 69.3% of TAC (337 t) North Island),  customary catch, recreational catch, and other sources of fishing related mortality (Jellyman 2007, 2012). New Zealand’s indigenous people, Māori, have been allocated 20% of commercial quota, with additional catch allocation for customary take (Jellyman 2007, Williams et al. 2017). Quota shares generate a certain amount of Annual Catch Entitlement (ACE), which does not necessarily have to be fished by owners themselves and can be sold to other licensed fishers that may or may not own quota. The proportion of the TAC given as customary allowance is different for both North and South Islands and can vary in different years as a result of adjustments made after reviews. The current customary allowance for the North Island is 15.2% of the TAC (74 t) after cuts to the TAC/TACC were made on 1st October 2018, although this varies within each Quota Management Area (QMA) (Ministry for Primary Industries 2019b). In the South Island the customary allowance is 19.8% of TAC (65 t), with the proportion again varying by QMA (values for TAC, TACC, cust. allowance, and rec. allowance for each North and South Island QMA can be found: Ministry for Primary Industries 2019c) (Ministry for Primary Industries 2019c).

Minimum and maximum commercial size limits (220 g from 1992 and 4 kg from 1995 for South Island and 2007 for North Island) are in place for anguillid eels throughout New Zealand (Jellyman 2012). The minimum size limit effectively excludes male shortfins, and so the fishery targets female yellow eels (Fisheries New Zealand 2018). In 2005, Mohaka, Motu and most of the Whanganui River catchments were closed to commercial fishing (Fisheries New Zealand 2018). In the Waikato-Tainui rohe region in 2014, bylaws were introduced to limit minimum harvest sizes to 300 g for ‘shortfins’ and 400 g for ‘longfins’, with an upper limit of 2 kg for both (Fisheries New Zealand 2018), to prevent the take of migratory females. There is now no targeted silver eel fishery, with exception of seaward migrating A. australis males under 220 g from Te Waihora (Fisheries New Zealand 2018). There was also the addition of seasonal closures in some reaches as a result of the introduced bylaws (Fisheries New Zealand 2018). Across New Zealand, there also exists a recreational daily bag limit of six eels, introduced in October 1994 (Fisheries New Zealand 2018). Commercial fishing in New Zealand is also banned in National Parks and Scenic Reserves, and often on the Crown Estate (managed by the Department of Conservation). In April 2018, the National Institute of Water and Atmospheric Research and Department of Conservation developed the “New Zealand fish passage guidelines: for structures up to 4 m” in partnership with the New Zealand Fish Passage Advisory Group (Doc.govt.nz 2018, Franklin et al. 2018). The document outlines recommended practice for the design of instream infrastructure to provide for general fish passage and sets foundations for improved fish passage management, making some reference to eels specifically (Doc.govt.nz 2018, Franklin et al. 2018). Other management measures have included enhancement of upstream waters with juvenile eels although where this takes place upstream of hydro dams, escapement still remains an issue; setting aside additional reserve areas to increase escapement of silver eels; and increased management involvement of Māori (Jellyman 2007).

Since 1982/3 assistance of upstream elver passage over hydro-dams has occurred in New Zealand, and ‘trap and transfer’ methods are used to help improve the state of eel populations above these structures (Boubée et al. 2008). Lake Manapouri in the Waiau River catchment operates the largest hydropower station in New Zealand (Jellyman and Unwin 2018). To provide safe downstream passage egress for silver eels, Meridian Energy Ltd. - the power company responsible for the Manapouri Lake Control structure - are required to operate a ‘trap and transfer’ and monitoring programme, whereby silver eels are caught in the lake and transferred downstream of the obstruction to allow access to the sea (Jellyman and Unwin 2018, Stuart et al. 2018). Methods allowing for downstream movement include netting eels in headraces, and opening spillway gates at critical times, such as at the Patea Dam in Taranaki, where spillway gates are opened for an hour after sunset following heavy rain when mature eels are likely to migrate (PCE 2013). Māori have also practised various forms of management, named “rāhui”, which has included imposing fishing bans on waterways for ceremonial or conservation reasons and seeding areas with small eels (Jellyman 2012).
